column1: ISFP	 I.ANCESTRY--BIRTH--BOYHOOD.My family is American
column2: and has been for generations
column3: in all itsbranches
column4: direct and collateral.Mathew Grant
column5: the founder of the branch in America
column6: of which I am adescendant
column7: reached Dorchester
column8: Massachusetts
column9: in May
column10: 1630.  In 1635 hemoved to what is now Windsor
column11: Connecticut
column12: and was the surveyor for thatcolony for more than forty years.  He was also
column13: for many years of thetime
column14: town clerk.  He was a married man when he arrived at Dorchester
column15: but his children were all born in this country.  His eldest son
column16: Samuel
column17: took lands on the east side of the Connecticut River
column18: opposite Windsor
column19: which have been held and occupied by descendants of his to this day.I am of the eighth generation from Mathew Grant
column20: and seventh fromSamuel.  Mathew Grant's first wife died a few years after theirsettlement in Windsor
column21: and he soon after married the widow Rockwell
column22: who
column23: with her first husband
column24: had been fellow-passengers with him and hisfirst wife
column25: on the ship Mary and John
column26: from Dorchester
column27: England
column28: in1630.  Mrs. Rockwell had several children by her first marriage
column29: andothers by her second.  By intermarriage
column30: two or three generations later
column31: I am descended from both the wives of Mathew Grant.In the fifth descending generation my great grandfather
column32: Noah Grant
column33: andhis younger brother
column34: Solomon
column35: held commissions in the English army
column37: in the war against the French and Indians.  Both were killed thatyear.My grandfather
column38: also named Noah

column40: after the battles of Concordand Lexington
column41: he went with a Connecticut company to join theContinental army
column42: and was present at the battle of Bunker Hill.  Heserved until the fall of Yorktown

column44: however

column46: had two children
column47: and was a widower at theclose.  Soon after this he emigrated to Westmoreland County
column48: Pennsylvania
column49: and settled near the town of Greensburg in that county.He took with him the younger of his two children
column50: Peter Grant.  Theelder
column51: Solomon
column52: remained with his relatives in Connecticut until oldenough to do for himself
column53: when he emigrated to the British West Indies.Not long after his settlement in Pennsylvania
column54: my grandfather
column55: CaptainNoah Grant
column56: married a Miss Kelly
column57: and in 1799 he emigrated again
column58: thistime to Ohio
column59: and settled where the town of Deerfield now stands.  Hehad now five children
column60: including Peter
column61: a son by his first marriage.  Myfather
column62: Jesse R. Grant
column63: was the second child--oldest son
column64: by the secondmarriage.Peter Grant went early to Maysville
column65: Kentucky
column66: where he was veryprosperous
column67: married
column68: had a family of nine children

column70: Virginia

column74: ' and
column75: after the death of his second wife

column87: Ibelieve

column95: andlived in the family of a Mr. Brown

column97: while his soul goes marching on.'  Ihave often heard my father speak of John Brown
column98: particularly since theevents at Harper's Ferry.  Brown was a boy when they lived in the samehouse
column99: but he knew him afterwards
column100: and regarded him as a man of greatpurity of character
column101: of high moral and physical courage

column103: and the overthrow ofslavery
column104: with less than twenty men.My father set up for himself in business
column105: establishing a tannery atRavenna
column106: the county seat of Portage County.  In a few years he removedfrom Ravenna
column107: and set up the same business at Point Pleasant
column108: ClermontCounty
column109: Ohio.During the minority of my father

column112: almost exclusively

column1: ISFP	 I have often heard him say thathis time at school was limited to six months
column2: when he was very young
column3: too young
column4: indeed
column5: to learn much
column6: or to appreciate the advantages of aneducation
column7: and to a 'quarter's schooling' afterwards
column8: probably whileliving with judge Tod.  But his thirst for education was intense.  Helearned rapidly
column9: and was a constant reader up to the day of his death inhis eightieth year.  Books were scarce in the Western Reserve during hisyouth
column10: but he read every book he could borrow in the neighborhood wherehe lived.  This scarcity gave him the early habit of studying everythinghe read
column11: so that when he got through with a book
column12: he knew everything init.  The habit continued through life.  Even after reading the dailypapers--which he never neglected--he could give all the importantinformation they contained.  He made himself an excellent Englishscholar
column13: and before he was twenty years of age was a constantcontributor to Western newspapers
column14: and was also
column15: from that time until hewas fifty years old
column16: an able debater in the societies for this purpose
column17: which were common in the West at that time.  He always took an activepart in politics
column18: but was never a candidate for office
column19: except
column20: Ibelieve
column21: that he was the first Mayor of Georgetown.  He supportedJackson for the Presidency; but he was a Whig
column22: a great admirer of HenryClay
column23: and never voted for any other democrat for high office afterJackson.My mother's family lived in Montgomery County
column24: Pennsylvania
column25: for severalgenerations.  I have little information about her ancestors.  Her familytook no interest in genealogy
column26: so that my grandfather
column27: who died when Iwas sixteen years old
column28: knew only back to his grandfather.  On the otherside
column29: my father took a great interest in the subject
column30: and in hisresearches

column32: Connecticut
column33: belonging to the family

column39: proved the title beyond dispute

column41: I think.  I remember thecircumstance well
column42: and remember
column43: too
column44: hearing him say on his return thathe found some widows living on the property

column46: John Simpson
column47: moved from Montgomery County
column48: Pennsylvania
column49: to Clermont County
column50: Ohio
column51: about the year 1819
column52: taking withhim his four children
column53: three daughters and one son.  My mother
column54: HannahSimpson
column55: was the third of these children
column56: and was then over twenty yearsof age.  Her oldest sister was at that time married
column57: and had severalchildren.  She still lives in Clermont County at this writing
column58: October5th
column60: and is over ninety ears of age.  Until her memory failed her
column61: a few years ago
column62: she thought the country ruined beyond recovery when theDemocratic party lost control in 1860.  Her family
column63: which was large
column64: inherited her views

column66: next of age and now past eighty-eight
column67: is also still livingin Clermont County
column68: within a few miles of the old homestead
column69: and is asactive in mind as ever.  He was a supporter of the Government during thewar
column70: and remains a firm believer
column71: that national success by theDemocratic party means irretrievable ruin.In June

column74: Jesse R. Grant
column75: married Hannah Simpson.  I wasborn on the 27th of April
column77: at Point Pleasant
column78: Clermont County
column79: Ohio.  In the fall of 1823 we moved to Georgetown

column81: the adjoining county east.  This place remained my home

column84: I went to West Point.The schools
column85: at the time of which I write
column86: were very indifferent.  Therewere no free schools
column87: and none in which the scholars were classified.They were all supported by subscription
column88: and a single teacher--who wasoften a man or a woman incapable of teaching much
column89: even if they impartedall they knew--would have thirty or forty scholars
column90: male and female
column91: from the infant learning the A B C's up to the young lady of eighteenand the boy of twenty
column92: studying the highest branches taught--the threeR's
column93: 'Reading
column94: 'Riting
column95: 'Rithmetic.'  I never saw an algebra
column96: or othermathematical work higher than the arithmetic
column97: in Georgetown
column98: until afterI was appointed to West Point.  I then bought a work on algebra inCincinnati; but having no teacher it was Greek to me.My life in Georgetown was uneventful.  From the age of five or six untilseventeen
column99: I attended the subscription schools of the village
column100: exceptduring the winters of 1836-7 and 1838-9.  The former period was spent inMaysville
column101: Kentucky
column102: attending the school of Richardson and Rand; thelatter in Ripley
column103: Ohio
column104: at a private school.  I was not studious inhabit
column105: and probably did not make progress enough to compensate for theoutlay for board and tuition.  At all events both winters were spent ingoing over the same old arithmetic which I knew every word of before
column106: and repeating:  'A noun is the name of a thing
column107: ' which I had also heardmy Georgetown teachers repeat
column108: until I had come to believe it--but Icast no reflections upon my old teacher
column109: Richardson. He turned outbright scholars from his school
column110: many of whom have filled conspicuousplaces in the service of their States.  Two of my contemporaries there--who
column111: I believe
column112: never attended any other institution of learning--haveheld seats in Congress
column113: and one
column114: if not both
column115: other high offices; theseare Wadsworth and Brewster.My father was
column116: from my earliest recollection
column117: in comfortablecircumstances
column118: considering the times
column119: his place of residence
column120: and thecommunity in which he lived.  Mindful of his own lack of facilities foracquiring an education
column121: his greatest desire in maturer years was for theeducation of his children. Consequently
column122: as stated before
column123: I nevermissed a quarter from school from the time I was old enough to attendtill the time of leaving home.  This did not exempt me from labor.  Inmy early days
column124: every one labored more or less
column125: in the region where myyouth was spent
column126: and more in proportion to their private means.  It wasonly the very poor who were exempt.  While my father carried on themanufacture of leather and worked at the trade himself
column127: he owned andtilled considerable land.  I detested the trade
column128: preferring almost anyother labor; but I was fond of agriculture
column129: and of all employment inwhich horses were used.  We had
column130: among other lands

column132: I began hauling all the wood used in thehouse and shops.  I could not load it on the wagons
column133: of course
column134: at thattime
column135: but I could drive
column136: and the choppers would load
column137: and some one atthe house unload.  When about eleven years old
column138: I was strong enough tohold a plough.  From that age until seventeen I did all the work donewith horses
column139: such as breaking up the land
column140: furrowing
column141: ploughing corn andpotatoes
column142: bringing in the crops when harvested
column143: hauling all the wood
column144: besides tending two or three horses
column145: a cow or two
column146: and sawing wood forstoves
column147: etc.
column148: while still attending school.  For this I was compensatedby the fact that there was never any scolding or punishing by myparents; no objection to rational enjoyments
column149: such as fishing
column150: going tothe creek a mile away to swim in summer
column151: taking a horse and visiting mygrandparents in the adjoining county

column153: skating on theice in winter
column154: or taking a horse and sleigh when there was snow on theground.While still quite young I had visited Cincinnati

column156: several times
column158: Kentucky
column159: often
column160: and onceLouisville.  The journey to Louisville was a big one for a boy of thatday.  I had also gone once with a two-horse carriage to Chilicothe

column162: with a neighbor's family
column163: who were removing toToledo

column1: ISFP	 While at Flat Rock
column2: at the house of a Mr.Payne
column3: whom I was visiting with his brother
column4: a neighbor of ours inGeorgetown
column5: I saw a very fine saddle horse
column6: which I rather coveted
column7: andproposed to Mr. Payne
column8: the owner
column9: to trade him for one of the two I wasdriving.  Payne hesitated to trade with a boy
column10: but asking his brotherabout it
column11: the latter told him that it would be all right
column12: that I wasallowed to do as I pleased with the horses.  I was seventy miles fromhome
column13: with a carriage to take back
column14: and Mr. Payne said he did not knowthat his horse had ever had a collar on.  I asked to have him hitched toa farm wagon and we would soon see whether he would work.  It was soonevident that the horse had never worn harness before; but he showed noviciousness
column15: and I expressed a confidence that I could manage him.  Atrade was at once struck
column16: I receiving ten dollars difference.The next day Mr. Payne
column17: of Georgetown
column18: and I started on our return.  Wegot along very well for a few miles
column19: when we encountered a ferocious dogthat frightened the horses and made them run.  The new animal kicked atevery jump he made.  I got the horses stopped
column20: however
column21: before anydamage was done
column22: and without running into anything.  After giving them alittle rest
column23: to quiet their fears
column24: we started again.  That instant thenew horse kicked
column25: and started to run once more.  The road we were on
column26: struck the turnpike within half a mile of the point where the secondrunaway commenced
column27: and there there was an embankment twenty or more feetdeep on the opposite side of the pike.  I got the horses stopped on thevery brink of the precipice.  My new horse was terribly frightened andtrembled like an aspen; but he was not half so badly frightened as mycompanion
column28: Mr. Payne
column29: who deserted me after this last experience
column30: andtook passage on a freight wagon for Maysville.  Every time I attemptedto start
column31: my new horse would commence to kick.  I was in quite a dilemmafor a time.  Once in Maysville I could borrow a horse from an uncle wholived there; but I was more than a day's travel from that point.Finally I took out my bandanna--the style of handkerchief in universaluse then--and with this blindfolded my horse.  In this way I reachedMaysville safely the next day
column32: no doubt much to the surprise of myfriend.  Here I borrowed a horse from my uncle
column33: and the following day weproceeded on our journey.About half my school-days in Georgetown were spent at the school of JohnD. White
column34: a North Carolinian
column35: and the father of Chilton White whorepresented the district in Congress for one term during the rebellion.Mr. White was always a Democrat in politics
column36: and Chilton followed hisfather.  He had two older brothers--all three being school-mates of mineat their father's school--who did not go the same way.  The secondbrother died before the rebellion began; he was a Whig
column37: and afterwards aRepublican.  His oldest brother was a Republican and brave soldierduring the rebellion.  Chilton is reported as having told of an earlierhorse-trade of mine.  As he told the story
column38: there was a Mr. Ralstonliving within a few miles of the village
column39: who owned a colt which I verymuch wanted.  My father had offered twenty dollars for it
column40: but Ralstonwanted twenty-five.  I was so anxious to have the colt
column41: that after theowner left
column42: I begged to be allowed to take him at the price demanded.My father yielded
column43: but said twenty dollars was all the horse was worth
column44: and told me to offer that price; if it was not accepted I was to offertwenty-two and a half
column45: and if that would not get him
column46: to give thetwenty-five.  I at once mounted a horse and went for the colt.  When Igot to Mr. Ralston's house
column47: I said to him:  'Papa says I may offer youtwenty dollars for the colt
column48: but if you won't take that
column49: I am to offertwenty-two and a half
column50: and if you won't take that
column51: to give youtwenty-five.'  It would not require a Connecticut man to guess the pricefinally agreed upon.  This story is nearly true.  I certainly showedvery plainly that I had come for the colt and meant to have him.  Icould not have been over eight years old at the time.  This transactioncaused me great heart-burning. The story got out among the boys of thevillage
column52: and it was a long time before I heard the last of it.  Boysenjoy the misery of their companions
column53: at least village boys in that daydid
column54: and in later life I have found that all adults are not free fromthe peculiarity.  I kept the horse until he was four years old
column55: when hewent blind
column56: and I sold him for twenty dollars.  When I went to Maysvilleto school
column58: at the age of fourteen
column59: I recognized my colt as oneof the blind horses working on the tread-wheel of the ferry-boat.I have describes enough of my early life to give an impression of thewhole.  I did not like to work; but I did as much of it
column60: while young
column61: asgrown men can be hired to do in these days
column62: and attended school at thesame time.  I had as many privileges as any boy in the village
column63: andprobably more than most of them.  I have no recollection of ever havingbeen punished at home
column64: either by scolding or by the rod.  But at schoolthe case was different.  The rod was freely used there
column65: and I was notexempt from its influence.  I can see John D. White--the school teacher--now
column66: with his long beech switch always in his hand.  It was not alwaysthe same one
column67: either.  Switches were brought in bundles
column68: from a beechwood near the school house
column69: by the boys for whose benefit they wereintended.  Often a whole bundle would be used up in a single day.  Inever had any hard feelings against my teacher
column70: either while attendingthe school
column71: or in later years when reflecting upon my experience.  Mr.White was a kindhearted man
column72: and was much respected by the community inwhich he lived.  He only followed the universal custom of the period
column73: and that under which he had received his own education.

column1: ISFP	 II.WEST POINT--GRADUATION.In the winter of 1838-9 I was attending school at Ripley
column2: only ten milesdistant from Georgetown
column3: but spent the Christmas holidays at home.During this vacation my father received a letter from the HonorableThomas Morris
column4: then United States Senator from Ohio.  When he read it hesaid to me
column5: 'Ulysses
column6: I believe you are going to receive theappointment.'  'What appointment?'  I inquired.  'To West Point; I haveapplied for it.'  'But I won't go
column7: ' I said.  He said he thought I would
column8: AND I THOUGHT SO TOO
column9: IF HE DID.  I really had no objection to going toWest Point
column10: except that I had a very exalted idea of the acquirementsnecessary to get through.  I did not believe I possessed them
column11: and couldnot bear the idea of failing.  There had been four boys from ourvillage
column12: or its immediate neighborhood
column13: who had been graduated from WestPoint
column14: and never a failure of any one appointed from Georgetown
column15: exceptin the case of the one whose place I was to take.  He was the son of Dr.Bailey
column16: our nearest and most intimate neighbor.  Young Bailey had beenappointed in 1837.  Finding before the January examination following
column17: that he could not pass
column18: he resigned and went to a private school
column19: andremained there until the following year
column20: when he was reappointed.Before the next examination he was dismissed.  Dr. Bailey was a proudand sensitive man
column21: and felt the failure of his son so keenly that heforbade his return home.  There were no telegraphs in those days todisseminate news rapidly
column22: no railroads west of the Alleghanies
column23: and butfew east; and above all
column24: there were no reporters prying into otherpeople's private affairs.  Consequently it did not become generallyknown that there was a vacancy at West Point from our district until Iwas appointed.  I presume Mrs. Bailey confided to my mother the factthat Bartlett had been dismissed
column25: and that the doctor had forbidden hisson's return home.The Honorable Thomas L. Hamer
column26: one of the ablest men Ohio ever produced
column27: was our member of Congress at the time
column28: and had the right of nomination.He and my father had been members of the same debating society (wherethey were generally pitted on opposite sides)
column29: and intimate personalfriends from their early manhood up to a few years before.  In politicsthey differed. Hamer was a life-long Democrat
column30: while my father was aWhig. They had a warm discussion
column31: which finally became angry--over someact of President Jackson
column32: the removal of the deposit of public moneys
column33: Ithink--after which they never spoke until after my appointment.  I knowboth of them felt badly over this estrangement
column34: and would have been gladat any time to come to a reconciliation; but neither would make theadvance.  Under these circumstances my father would not write to Hamerfor the appointment
column35: but he wrote to Thomas Morris
column36: United StatesSenator from Ohio
column37: informing him that there was a vacancy at West Pointfrom our district
column38: and that he would be glad if I could be appointed tofill it.  This letter
column39: I presume
column40: was turned over to Mr. Hamer
column41: and
column42: asthere was no other applicant
column43: he cheerfully appointed me.  This healedthe breach between the two
column44: never after reopened.Besides the argument used by my father in favor of my going to WestPoint--that 'he thought I would go'--there was another very stronginducement.

column1: ISFP	 I had always a great desire to travel.  I was already thebest travelled boy in Georgetown
column2: except the sons of one man
column3: JohnWalker
column4: who had emigrated to Texas with his family
column5: and immigrated backas soon as he could get the means to do so.  In his short stay in Texashe acquired a very different opinion of the country from what one wouldform going there now.I had been east to Wheeling
column6: Virginia
column7: and north to the Western Reserve
column8: in Ohio
column9: west to Louisville
column10: and south to Bourbon County
column11: Kentucky
column12: besides having driven or ridden pretty much over the whole countrywithin fifty miles of home.  Going to West Point would give me theopportunity of visiting the two great cities of the continent
column13: Philadelphia and New York.  This was enough.  When these places werevisited I would have been glad to have had a steamboat or railroadcollision
column14: or any other accident happen
column15: by which I might have receiveda temporary injury sufficient to make me ineligible
column16: for a time
column17: toenter the Academy.  Nothing of the kind occurred
column18: and I had to face themusic.Georgetown has a remarkable record for a western village.  It is
column19: andhas been from its earliest existence
column20: a democratic town.  There wasprobably no time during the rebellion when
column21: if the opportunity couldhave been afforded
column22: it would not have voted for Jefferson Davis forPresident of the United States
column23: over Mr. Lincoln
column24: or any otherrepresentative of his party; unless it was immediately after some ofJohn Morgan's men
column25: in his celebrated raid through Ohio
column26: spent a fewhours in the village.  The rebels helped themselves to whatever theycould find
column27: horses
column28: boots and shoes
column29: especially horses
column30: and many orderedmeals to be prepared for them by the families.  This was no doubt a farpleasanter duty for some families than it would have been to render alike service for Union soldiers.  The line between the Rebel and Unionelement in Georgetown was so marked that it led to divisions even in thechurches.  There were churches in that part of Ohio where treason waspreached regularly
column31: and where
column32: to secure membership
column33: hostility to thegovernment
column34: to the war and to the liberation of the slaves
column35: was far moreessential than a belief in the authenticity or credibility of the Bible.There were men in Georgetown who filled all the requirements formembership in these churches.Yet this far-off western village
column36: with a population
column37: including old andyoung
column38: male and female
column39: of about one thousand--about enough for theorganization of a single regiment if all had been men capable of bearingarms--furnished the Union army four general officers and one colonel
column40: West Point graduates
column41: and nine generals and field officers ofVolunteers
column42: that I can think of. Of the graduates from West Point
column43: allhad citizenship elsewhere at the breaking out of the rebellion
column44: exceptpossibly General A. V. Kautz
column45: who had remained in the army from hisgraduation.  Two of the colonels also entered the service from otherlocalities.  The other seven
column46: General McGroierty
column47: Colonels White
column48: Fyffe
column49: Loudon and Marshall
column50: Majors King and Bailey
column51: were all residents ofGeorgetown when the war broke out
column52: and all of them
column53: who were alive atthe close
column54: returned there.  Major Bailey was the cadet who had precededme at West Point.  He was killed in West Virginia
column55: in his firstengagement.  As far as I know
column56: every boy who has entered West Point fromthat village since my time has been graduated.I took passage on a steamer at Ripley
column57: Ohio
column58: for Pittsburg
column59: about themiddle of May
column60: 1839.  Western boats at that day did not make regulartrips at stated times
column61: but would stop anywhere
column62: and for any length oftime
column63: for passengers or freight.  I have myself been detained two orthree days at a place after steam was up
column64: the gang planks
column65: all but one
column66: drawn in
column67: and after the time advertised for starting had expired.  Onthis occasion we had no vexatious delays
column68: and in about three daysPittsburg was reached.  From Pittsburg I chose passage by the canal toHarrisburg
column69: rather than by the more expeditious stage.  This gave abetter opportunity of enjoying the fine scenery of Western Pennsylvania
column70: and I had rather a dread of reaching my destination at all.  At thattime the canal was much patronized by travellers
column71: and
column72: with thecomfortable packets of the period

column113: and earlyevening.  McClernand was advanced as soon as ammunition and two days'rations (to last five) could be issued to his men.  The bluffs werereached an hour before sunset and McClernand was pushed on

column115: too

column117: Vicksburg and Jackson.McClernand's advance met the enemy about five miles west of Port Gibsonat Thompson's plantation.  There was some firing during the night

column119: numbering about seven or eight thousand men
column120: under General Bowen.  Hishope was to hold me in check until reinforcements under Loring couldreach him from Vicksburg; but Loring did not come in time to render muchassistance south of Port Gibson.  Two brigades of McPherson's corpsfollowed McClernand as fast as rations and ammunition could be issued
column121: and were ready to take position upon the battlefield whenever the 13thcorps could be got out of the way.The country in this part of Mississippi stands on edge
column122: as it were

column128: the road to Port Gibsondivides

column131: Carr and A. J. Smith upon the right-hand branch and Osterhaus onthe left.  I was on the field by ten A.M.
column132: and inspected both flanks inperson.  On the right the enemy
column133: if not being pressed back
column134: was at leastnot repulsing our advance.  On the left
column135: however
column136: Osterhaus was notfaring so well.  He had been repulsed with some loss.  As soon as theroad could be cleared of McClernand's troops I ordered up McPherson
column137: whowas close upon the rear of the 13th corps
column138: with two brigades of Logan'sdivision.  This was about noon.  I ordered him to send one brigade(General John E. Smith's was selected) to support Osterhaus
column139: and to moveto the left and flank the enemy out of his position.  This movementcarried the brigade over a deep ravine to a third ridge and
column140: whenSmith's troops were seen well through the ravine

column142: and their leftfollowed before sunset.  While the movement to our left was going on
column143: McClernand
column144: who was with his right flank
column145: sent me frequent requests forreinforcements
column146: although the force with him was not being pressed.  Ihad been upon the ground and knew it did not admit of his engaging allthe men he had.  We followed up our victory until night overtook usabout two miles from Port Gibson; then the troops went into bivouac forthe night.

column1: ISFP	 XXXIV.CAPTURE OF PORT GIBSON--GRIERSON'S RAID--OCCUPATION OF GRAND GULF--MOVEMENT UP THE BIG BLACK--BATTLE OF RAYMOND.We started next morning for Port Gibson as soon as it was light enoughto see the road.  We were soon in the town
column2: and I was delighted to findthat the enemy had not stopped to contest our crossing further at thebridge
column3: which he had burned.  The troops were set to work at once toconstruct a bridge across the South Fork of the Bayou Pierre.  At thistime the water was high and the current rapid.  What might be called araft-bridge was soon constructed from material obtained from woodenbuildings
column4: stables
column5: fences
column6: etc.
column7: which sufficed for carrying the wholearmy over safely.  Colonel J. H. Wilson
column8: a member of my staff
column9: plannedand superintended the construction of this bridge
column10: going into the waterand working as hard as any one engaged.  Officers and men generallyjoined in this work.  When it was finished the army crossed and marchedeight miles beyond to the North Fork that day.  One brigade of Logan'sdivision was sent down the stream to occupy the attention of a rebelbattery
column11: which had been left behind with infantry supports to preventour repairing the burnt railroad bridge.  Two of his brigades were sentup the bayou to find a crossing and reach the North Fork to repair thebridge there.  The enemy soon left when he found we were building abridge elsewhere.  Before leaving Port Gibson we were reinforced byCrocker's division
column12: McPherson's corps
column13: which had crossed the Mississippiat Bruinsburg and come up without stopping except to get two days'rations.  McPherson still had one division west of the MississippiRiver
column14: guarding the road from Milliken's Bend to the river below untilSherman's command should relieve it.On leaving Bruinsburg for the front I left my son Frederick
column15: who hadjoined me a few weeks before
column16: on board one of the gunboats asleep
column17: andhoped to get away without him until after Grand Gulf should fall intoour hands; but on waking up he learned that I had gone
column18: and being guidedby the sound of the battle raging at Thompson's Hill--called the Battleof Port Gibson--found his way to where I was.  He had no horse to rideat the time
column19: and I had no facilities for even preparing a meal.  He
column20: therefore
column21: foraged around the best he could until we reached Grand Gulf.Mr. C. A. Dana
column22: then an officer of the War Department
column23: accompanied me onthe Vicksburg campaign and through a portion of the siege.  He was inthe same situation as Fred so far as transportation and messarrangements were concerned.  The first time I call to mind seeingeither of them
column24: after the battle
column25: they were mounted on two enormoushorses
column26: grown white from age
column27: each equipped with dilapidated saddles andbridles.Our trains arrived a few days later
column28: after which we were all perfectlyequipped.My son accompanied me throughout the campaign and siege
column29: and caused noanxiety either to me or to his mother
column30: who was at home.  He looked outfor himself and was in every battle of the campaign.  His age
column31: then notquite thirteen
column32: enabled him to take in all he saw
column33: and to retain arecollection of it that would not be possible in more mature years.When the movement from Bruinsburg commenced we were without a wagontrain.  The train still west of the Mississippi was carried around withproper escort
column34: by a circuitous route from Milliken's Bend to Hard Timesseventy or more miles below
column35: and did not get up for some days after thebattle of Port Gibson. My own horses
column36: headquarters' transportation
column37: servants
column38: mess chest
column39: and everything except what I had on
column40: was with thistrain. General A. J. Smith happened to have an extra horse at Bruinsburgwhich I borrowed
column41: with a saddle-tree without upholstering further thanstirrups.  I had no other for nearly a week.It was necessary to have transportation for ammunition. Provisions couldbe taken from the country; but all the ammunition that can be carried onthe person is soon exhausted when there is much fighting.  I directed
column42: therefore
column43: immediately on landing that all the vehicles and draftanimals
column44: whether horses
column45: mules
column46: or oxen
column47: in the vicinity should becollected and loaded to their capacity with ammunition.  Quite a trainwas collected during the 30th
column48: and a motley train it was.  In it couldbe found fine carriages
column49: loaded nearly to the top with boxes ofcartridges that had been pitched in promiscuously
column50: drawn by mules withplough
column51: harness
column52: straw collars
column53: rope-lines
column54: etc.; long-coupled wagons
column55: with racks for carrying cotton bales
column56: drawn by oxen
column57: and everything thatcould be found in the way of transportation on a plantation
column58: either foruse or pleasure.  The making out of provision returns was stopped forthe time.  No formalities were to retard our progress until a positionwas secured when the time could be spared to observe them.It was at Port Gibson I first heard through a Southern paper of thecomplete success of Colonel Grierson
column59: who was making a raid throughcentral Mississippi.  He had started from La Grange April 17th withthree regiments of about 1
column60: 700 men.  On the 21st he had detached ColonelHatch with one regiment to destroy the railroad between Columbus andMacon and then return to La Grange.  Hatch had a sharp fight with theenemy at Columbus and retreated along the railroad
column61: destroying it atOkalona and Tupelo
column62: and arriving in La Grange April 26.  Griersoncontinued his movement with about 1
column63: 000 men
column64: breaking the Vicksburg andMeridian railroad and the New Orleans and Jackson railroad
column65: arriving atBaton Rouge May 2d.  This raid was of great importance
column66: for Grierson hadattracted the attention of the enemy from the main movement againstVicksburg.During the night of the 2d of May the bridge over the North Fork wasrepaired
column67: and the troops commenced crossing at five the next morning.Before the leading brigade was over it was fired upon by the enemy froma commanding position; but they were soon driven off.  It was evidentthat the enemy was covering a retreat from Grand Gulf to Vicksburg.Every commanding position from this (Grindstone) crossing to Hankinson'sferry over the Big Black was occupied by the retreating foe to delay ourprogress. McPherson
column68: however
column69: reached Hankinson's ferry before night
column70: seized the ferry boat
column71: and sent a detachment of his command across andseveral miles north on the road to Vicksburg.  When the junction of theroad going to Vicksburg with the road from Grand Gulf to Raymond andJackson was reached
column72: Logan with his division was turned to the lefttowards Grand Gulf.  I went with him a short distance from thisjunction.  McPherson had encountered the largest force yet met since thebattle of Port Gibson and had a skirmish nearly approaching a battle;but the road Logan had taken enabled him to come up on the enemy's rightflank
column73: and they soon gave way.  McPherson was ordered to holdHankinson's ferry and the road back to Willow Springs with one division;McClernand
column74: who was now in the rear
column75: was to join in this as well as toguard the line back down the bayou.  I did not want to take the chancesof having an enemy lurking in our rear.On the way from the junction to Grand Gulf
column76: where the road comes intothe one from Vicksburg to the same place six or seven miles out
column77: Ilearned that the last of the enemy had retreated past that place ontheir way to Vicksburg.  I left Logan to make the proper disposition ofhis troops for the night
column78: while I rode into the town with an escort ofabout twenty cavalry.  Admiral Porter had already arrived with hisfleet.  The enemy had abandoned his heavy guns and evacuated the place.When I reached Grand Gulf May 3d I had not been with my baggage sincethe 27th of April and consequently had had no change of underclothing
column79: no meal except such as I could pick up sometimes at other headquarters
column80: and no tent to cover me.  The first thing I did was to get a bath
column81: borrow some fresh underclothing from one of the naval officers andget a good meal on the flag-ship.  Then I wrote letters to thegeneral-in-chief informing him of our present position
column82: dispatches to betelegraphed from Cairo
column83: orders to General Sullivan commanding aboveVicksburg
column84: and gave orders to all my corps commanders.  About twelveo'clock at night I was through my work and started for Hankinson'sferry
column85: arriving there before daylight.  While at Grand Gulf I heard fromBanks
column86: who was on the Red River
column87: and who said that he could not be atPort Hudson before the 10th of May and then with only 15
column88: 000 men.  Up tothis time my intention had been to secure Grand Gulf
column89: as a base ofsupplies
column90: detach McClernand's corps to Banks and co-operate with him inthe reduction of Port Hudson.The news from Banks forced upon me a different plan of campaign from theone intended.  To wait for his co-operation would have detained me atleast a month.  The reinforcements would not have reached ten thousandmen after deducting casualties and necessary river guards at all highpoints close to the river for over three hundred miles.  The enemy wouldhave strengthened his position and been reinforced by more men thanBanks could have brought. I therefore determined to move independentlyof Banks
column91: cut loose from my base
column92: destroy the rebel force in rear ofVicksburg and invest or capture the city.Grand Gulf was accordingly given up as a base and the authorities atWashington were notified.  I knew well that Halleck's caution would leadhim to disapprove of this course; but it was the only one that gave anychance of success.  The time it would take to communicate withWashington and get a reply would be so great that I could not beinterfered with until it was demonstrated whether my plan waspracticable.  Even Sherman
column93: who afterwards ignored bases of suppliesother than what were afforded by the country while marching through fourStates of the Confederacy with an army more than twice as large as mineat this time
column94: wrote me from Hankinson's ferry
column95: advising me of theimpossibility of supplying our army over a single road.  He urged me to'stop all troops till your army is partially supplied with wagons
column96: andthen act as quick as possible; for this road will be jammed
column97: as sure aslife.'  To this I replied:  'I do not calculate upon the possibility ofsupplying the army with full rations from Grand Gulf.  I know it will beimpossible without constructing additional roads.  What I do expect isto get up what rations of hard bread
column98: coffee and salt we can
column99: and makethe country furnish the balance.'  We started from Bruinsburg with anaverage of about two days' rations
column100: and received no more from our ownsupplies for some days; abundance was found in the mean time.  A delaywould give the enemy time to reinforce and fortify.McClernand's and McPherson's commands were kept substantially as theywere on the night of the 2d
column101: awaiting supplies sufficient to give themthree days' rations in haversacks.  Beef
column102: mutton
column103: poultry and foragewere found in abundance.  Quite a quantity of bacon and molasses wasalso secured from the country
column104: but bread and coffee could not beobtained in quantity sufficient for all the men.  Every plantation
column105: however
column106: had a run of stone
column107: propelled by mule power
column108: to grind corn forthe owners and their slaves.  All these were kept running while we werestopping
column109: day and night
column110: and when we were marching
column111: during the night
column112: atall plantations covered by the troops.  But the product was taken by thetroops nearest by
column113: so that the majority of the command was destined togo without bread until a new base was established on the Yazoo aboveVicksburg.While the troops were awaiting the arrival of rations I orderedreconnoissances made by McClernand and McPherson
column114: with the view ofleading the enemy to believe that we intended to cross the Big Black andattack the city at once.On the 6th Sherman arrived at Grand Gulf and crossed his command thatnight and the next day.  Three days' rations had been brought up fromGrand Gulf for the advanced troops and were issued.  Orders were givenfor a forward movement the next day.  Sherman was directed to order upBlair
column115: who had been left behind to guard the road from Milliken's Bendto Hard Times with two brigades.The quartermaster at Young's Point was ordered to send two hundredwagons with Blair
column116: and the commissary was to load them with hard bread
column117: coffee
column118: sugar
column119: salt and one hundred thousand pounds of salt meat.On the 3d Hurlbut
column120: who had been left at Memphis
column121: was ordered to sendfour regiments from his command to Milliken's Bend to relieve Blair'sdivision
column122: and on the 5th he was ordered to send Lauman's division inaddition
column123: the latter to join the army in the field.  The four regimentswere to be taken from troops near the river so that there would be nodelay.During the night of the 6th McPherson drew in his troops north of theBig Black and was off at an early hour on the road to Jackson
column124: via RockySprings
column125: Utica and Raymond.  That night he and McClernand were both atRocky Springs ten miles from Hankinson's ferry.  McPherson remainedthere during the 8th
column126: while McClernand moved to Big Sandy and Shermanmarched from Grand Gulf to Hankinson's ferry.  The 9th
column127: McPherson movedto a point within a few miles west of Utica; McClernand and Shermanremained where they were.  On the 10th McPherson moved to Utica
column128: Shermanto Big Sandy; McClernand was still at Big Sandy.  The 11th
column129: McClernandwas at Five Mile Creek; Sherman at Auburn; McPherson five miles advancedfrom Utica. May 12th
column130: McClernand was at Fourteen Mile Creek; Sherman atFourteen Mile Creek; McPherson at Raymond after a battle.After McPherson crossed the Big Black at Hankinson's ferry Vicksburgcould have been approached and besieged by the south side.  It is notprobable
column131: however
column132: that Pemberton would have permitted a closebesiegement.  The broken nature of the ground would have enabled him tohold a strong defensible line from the river south of the city to theBig Black
column133: retaining possession of the railroad back to that point.  Itwas my plan
column134: therefore
column135: to get to the railroad east of Vicksburg
column136: andapproach from that direction.  Accordingly
column137: McPherson's troops that hadcrossed the Big Black were withdrawn and the movement east to Jacksoncommenced.As has been stated before
column138: the country is very much broken and the roadsgenerally confined to the tops of the hills.  The troops were moved one(sometimes two) corps at a time to reach designated points out parallelto the railroad and only from six to ten miles from it.  McClernand'scorps was kept with its left flank on the Big Black guarding all thecrossings.  Fourteen Mile Creek
column139: a stream substantially parallel withthe railroad
column140: was reached and crossings effected by McClernand andSherman with slight loss.  McPherson was to the right of Sherman
column141: extending to Raymond.  The cavalry was used in this advance inreconnoitring to find the roads:  to cover our advances and to find themost practicable routes from one command to another so they couldsupport each other in case of an attack.  In making this move Iestimated Pemberton's movable force at Vicksburg at about eighteenthousand men
column142: with smaller forces at Haines' Bluff and Jackson.  Itwould not be possible for Pemberton to attack me with all his troops atone place
column143: and I determined to throw my army between his and fight himin detail.  This was done with success
column144: but I found afterwards that Ihad entirely under-estimated Pemberton's strength.Up to this point our movements had been made without serious opposition.My line was now nearly parallel with the Jackson and Vicksburg railroadand about seven miles south of it.  The right was at Raymond eighteenmiles from Jackson
column145: McPherson commanding; Sherman in the centre onFourteen Mile Creek
column146: his advance thrown across; McClernand to the left
column147: also on Fourteen Mile Creek
column148: advance across
column149: and his pickets within twomiles of Edward's station
column150: where the enemy had concentrated aconsiderable force and where they undoubtedly expected us to attack.McClernand's left was on the Big Black.  In all our moves
column151: up to thistime
column152: the left had hugged the Big Black closely
column153: and all the ferries hadbeen guarded to prevent the enemy throwing a force on our rear.McPherson encountered the enemy
column154: five thousand strong with two batteriesunder General Gregg
column155: about two miles out of Raymond. This was about twoP.M.  Logan was in advance with one of his brigades.  He deployed andmoved up to engage the enemy. McPherson ordered the road in rear to becleared of wagons
column156: and the balance of Logan's division
column158: which was still farther in rear
column159: to come forward with all dispatch.  Theorder was obeyed with alacrity.  Logan got his division in position forassault before Crocker could get up
column160: and attacked with vigor
column161: carryingthe enemy's position easily
column162: sending Gregg flying from the field not toappear against our front again until we met at Jackson.In this battle McPherson lost 66 killed
column163: 339 wounded
column164: and 37 missing--nearly or quite all from Logan's division.  The enemy's loss was 100killed
column165: 305 wounded
column166: besides 415 taken prisoners.I regarded Logan and Crocker as being as competent division commandersas could be found in or out of the army and both equal to a much highercommand.  Crocker
column167: however
column168: was dying of consumption when hevolunteered.  His weak condition never put him on the sick report whenthere was a battle in prospect
column169: as long as he could keep on his feet.He died not long after the close of the rebellion.

column1: ISFP	 XXXV.MOVEMENT AGAINST JACKSON--FALL OF JACKSON--INTERCEPTING THE ENEMY--BATTLE OF CHAMPION'S HILL.When the news reached me of McPherson's victory at Raymond about sundownmy position was with Sherman.  I decided at once to turn the wholecolumn towards Jackson and capture that place without delay.Pemberton was now on my left
column2: with
column3: as I supposed
column4: about 18
column5: 000 men; infact
column6: as I learned afterwards
column7: with nearly 50
column8: 000.  A force was alsocollecting on my right
column9: at Jackson
column10: the point where all the railroadscommunicating with Vicksburg connect. All the enemy's supplies of menand stores would come by that point.  As I hoped in the end to besiegeVicksburg I must first destroy all possibility of aid.  I thereforedetermined to move swiftly towards Jackson
column11: destroy or drive any forcein that direction and then turn upon Pemberton.  But by moving againstJackson
column12: I uncovered my own communication.  So I finally decided to havenone--to cut loose altogether from my base and move my whole forceeastward.  I then had no fears for my communications
column13: and if I movedquickly enough could turn upon Pemberton before he could attack me inthe rear.Accordingly
column14: all previous orders given during the day for movements onthe 13th were annulled by new ones.  McPherson was ordered at daylightto move on Clinton
column15: ten miles from Jackson; Sherman was notified of mydetermination to capture Jackson and work from there westward.  He wasordered to start at four in the morning and march to Raymond.McClernand was ordered to march with three divisions by Dillon's toRaymond.  One was left to guard the crossing of the Big Black.On the 10th I had received a letter from Banks
column16: on the Red River
column17: askingreinforcements.  Porter had gone to his assistance with a part of hisfleet on the 3d
column18: and I now wrote to him describing my position anddeclining to send any troops.  I looked upon side movements as long asthe enemy held Port Hudson and Vicksburg as a waste of time andmaterial.General Joseph E. Johnston arrived at Jackson in the night of the 13thfrom Tennessee
column19: and immediately assumed command of all the Confederatetroops in Mississippi.  I knew he was expecting reinforcements from thesouth and east. On the 6th I had written to General Halleck:'Information from the other side leaves me to believe the enemy arebringing forces from Tullahoma.'Up to this time my troops had been kept in supporting distances of eachother
column20: as far as the nature of the country would admit.  Reconnoissanceswere constantly made from each corps to enable them to acquaintthemselves with the most practicable routes from one to another in casea union became necessary.McPherson reached Clinton with the advance early on the 13th andimmediately set to work destroying the railroad.  Sherman's advancereached Raymond before the last of McPherson's command had got out ofthe town.  McClernand withdrew from the front of the enemy
column21: at Edward'sstation
column22: with much skill and without loss
column23: and reached his position forthe night in good order.  On the night of the 13th
column24: McPherson wasordered to march at early dawn upon Jackson
column25: only fifteen miles away.Sherman was given the same order; but he was to move by the direct roadfrom Raymond to Jackson
column26: which is south of the road McPherson was on anddoes not approach within two miles of it at the point where it crossedthe line of intrenchments which
column27: at that time
column28: defended the city.McClernand was ordered to move one division of his command to Clinton
column29: one division a few miles beyond Mississippi Springs following Sherman'sline
column30: and a third to Raymond.  He was also directed to send his siegeguns
column31: four in number with the troops going by Mississippi Springs.McClernand's position was an advantageous one in any event. With onedivision at Clinton he was in position to reinforce McPherson
column32: atJackson
column33: rapidly if it became necessary; the division beyond MississippiSprings was equally available to reinforce Sherman; the one at Raymondcould take either road. He still had two other divisions farther backnow that Blair had come up
column34: available within a day at Jackson.  If thislast command should not be wanted at Jackson
column35: they were already oneday's march from there on their way to Vicksburg and on three differentroads leading to the latter city.  But the most important considerationin my mind was to have a force confronting Pemberton if he should comeout to attack my rear. This I expected him to do; as shown further on
column36: he was directed by Johnston to make this very move.I notified General Halleck that I should attack the State capital on the14th.  A courier carried the dispatch to Grand Gulf through anunprotected country.Sherman and McPherson communicated with each other during the night andarranged to reach Jackson at about the same hour.  It rained in torrentsduring the night of the 13th and the fore part of the day of the 14th.The roads were intolerable
column37: and in some places on Sherman's line
column38: wherethe land was low
column39: they were covered more than a foot deep with water.But the troops never murmured.  By nine o'clock Crocker
column40: of McPherson'scorps
column41: who was now in advance
column42: came upon the enemy's pickets andspeedily drove them in upon the main body.  They were outside of theintrenchments in a strong position
column43: and proved to be the troops that hadbeen driven out of Raymond.  Johnston had been reinforced; during thenight by Georgia and South Carolina regiments
column44: so that his forceamounted to eleven thousand men
column45: and he was expecting still more.Sherman also came upon the rebel pickets some distance out from thetown
column46: but speedily drove them in.  He was now on the south andsouth-west of Jackson confronting the Confederates behind theirbreastworks
column47: while McPherson's right was nearly two miles north
column48: occupying a line running north and south across the Vicksburg railroad.Artillery was brought up and reconnoissances made preparatory to anassault. McPherson brought up Logan's division while he deployedCrocker's for the assault.  Sherman made similar dispositions on theright.  By eleven A.M. both were ready to attack.  Crocker moved hisdivision forward
column49: preceded by a strong skirmish line.  These troops atonce encountered the enemy's advance and drove it back on the main body
column50: when they returned to their proper regiment and the whole divisioncharged
column51: routing the enemy completely and driving him into this mainline.  This stand by the enemy was made more than two miles outside ofhis main fortifications. McPherson followed up with his command untilwithin range of the guns of the enemy from their intrenchments
column52: when hehalted to bring his troops into line and reconnoitre to determine thenext move.  It was now about noon.While this was going on Sherman was confronting a rebel battery whichenfiladed the road on which he was marching--the Mississippi Springsroad--and commanded a bridge spanning a stream over which he had topass.  By detaching right and left the stream was forced and the enemyflanked and speedily driven within the main line.  This brought ourwhole line in front of the enemy's line of works
column53: which was continuouson the north
column54: west and south sides from the Pearl River north of thecity to the same river south.  I was with Sherman.  He was confronted bya force sufficient to hold us back.  Appearances did not justify anassault where we were.  I had directed Sherman to send a force to theright
column55: and to reconnoitre as far as to the Pearl River.  This force
column56: Tuttle's division
column57: not returning I rode to the right with my staff
column58: andsoon found that the enemy had left that part of the line.  Tuttle'smovement or McPherson's pressure had no doubt led Johnston to order aretreat
column59: leaving only the men at the guns to retard us while he wasgetting away.  Tuttle had seen this and
column60: passing through the lineswithout resistance
column61: came up in the rear of the artillerists confrontingSherman and captured them with ten pieces of artillery.  I rodeimmediately to the State House
column62: where I was soon followed by Sherman.About the same time McPherson discovered that the enemy was leaving hisfront
column63: and advanced Crocker
column64: who was so close upon the enemy that theycould not move their guns or destroy them.  He captured seven guns and
column65: moving on
column66: hoisted the National flag over the rebel capital ofMississippi.  Stevenson's brigade was sent to cut off the rebel retreat
column67: but was too late or not expeditious enough.Our loss in this engagement was:  McPherson
column68: 37 killed
column69: 228 wounded;Sherman
column70: 4 killed and 21 wounded and missing.  The enemy lost 845killed
column71: wounded and captured.  Seventeen guns fell into our hands
column72: andthe enemy destroyed by fire their store-houses
column73: containing a largeamount of commissary stores.On this day Blair reached New Auburn and joined McClernand's 4thdivision.  He had with him two hundred wagons loaded with rations
column74: theonly commissary supplies received during the entire campaign.I slept that night in the room that Johnston was said to have occupiedthe night before.About four in the afternoon I sent for the corps commanders and directedthe dispositions to be made of their troops.  Sherman was to remain inJackson until he destroyed that place as a railroad centre
column75: andmanufacturing city of military supplies. He did the work mosteffectually.  Sherman and I went together into a manufactory which hadnot ceased work on account of the battle nor for the entrance of Yankeetroops.  Our presence did not seem to attract the attention of eitherthe manager or the operatives

column1: ISFP	 XXXVI.BATTLE OF BLACK RIVER BRIDGE--CROSSING THE BIG BLACK--INVESTMENT OFVICKSBURG--ASSAULTING THE WORKS.We were now assured of our position between Johnston and Pemberton
column2: without a possibility of a junction of their forces.  Pemberton mighthave made a night march to the Big Black
column3: crossed the bridge there and
column4: by moving north on the west side
column5: have eluded us and finally returned toJohnston.  But this would have given us Vicksburg.  It would have beenhis proper move
column6: however
column7: and the one Johnston would have made had hebeen in Pemberton's place.  In fact it would have been in conformitywith Johnston's orders to Pemberton.Sherman left Jackson with the last of his troops about noon on the 16thand reached Bolton
column8: twenty miles west
column9: before halting.  His rear guarddid not get in until two A.M. the 17th
column10: but renewed their march bydaylight.  He paroled his prisoners at Jackson
column11: and was forced to leavehis own wounded in care of surgeons and attendants.  At Bolton he wasinformed of our victory.  He was directed to commence the march earlynext day
column12: and to diverge from the road he was on to Bridgeport on theBig Black River
column13: some eleven miles above the point where we expected tofind the enemy.  Blair was ordered to join him there with the pontoontrain as early as possible.This movement brought Sherman's corps together
column14: and at a point where Ihoped a crossing of the Big Black might be effected and Sherman's corpsused to flank the enemy out of his position in our front
column15: thus opening acrossing for the remainder of the army.  I informed him that I wouldendeavor to hold the enemy in my front while he crossed the river.The advance division
column16: Carr's (McClernand's corps)

column18: followed closely by Osterhaus

column21: and was reached atan early hour.  Here the river makes a turn to the west
column22: and has washedclose up to the high land; the east side is a low bottom
column23: sometimesoverflowed at very high water
column24: but was cleared and in cultivation.  Abayou runs irregularly across this low land
column25: the bottom of which
column26: however
column27: is above the surface of the Big Black at ordinary stages.  Whenthe river is full water runs through it

The rebels had constructed a parapet along the inner bank of thisbayou by using cotton bales from the plantation close by and throwingdirt over them.  The whole was thoroughly commanded from the height westof the river.  At the upper end of the bayou there was a strip ofuncleared land which afforded a cover for a portion of our men.  Carr'sdivision was deployed on our right
column30: Lawler's brigade forming his extremeright and reaching through these woods to the river above.  Osterhaus'division was deployed to the left of Carr and covered the enemy's entirefront.  McPherson was in column on the road

Sherman's lineof march led him to the very point on Walnut Hills occupied by the enemythe December before when he was repulsed.  Sherman was equally anxiouswith myself.  Our impatience led us to move in advance of the column andwell up with the advanced skirmishers.  There were some detached worksalong the crest of the hill.  These were still occupied by the enemy

In a few minutes Sherman had the pleasure oflooking down from the spot coveted so much by him the December before onthe ground where his command had lain so helpless for offensive action.He turned to me

column59: however

column63: after crossing the Big Black

column69: one to the east and one to the south-east of the city.By the morning of the 19th the investment was as complete as my limitednumber of troops would allow.  Sherman was on the right

column76: however
column77: butbegan to feel the want of bread.  I remember that in passing around tothe left of the line on the 21st
column78: a soldier
column79: recognizing me
column80: said inrather a low voice
column81: but yet so that I heard him

column83: 'Hard tack! Hard tack!'I told the men nearest to me that we had been engaged ever since thearrival of the troops in building a road over which to supply them witheverything they needed.  The cry was instantly changed to cheers.  Bythe night of the 21st all the troops had full rations issued to them.The bread and coffee were highly appreciated.I now determined on a second assault.  Johnston was in my rear
column84: onlyfifty miles away
column85: with an army not much inferior in numbers to the one Ihad with me

column88: indeed

This last attack only served toincrease our casualties without giving any benefit whatever.  As soon asit was dark our troops that had reached the enemy's line and beenobliged to remain there for security all day
column96: were withdrawn; and thusended the last assault upon Vicksburg.

column1: ISFP	 XXXVIISIEGE OF VICKSBURG.I now determined upon a regular siege--to 'out-camp the enemy
column2: ' as itwere
column3: and to incur no more losses.  The experience of the 22d convincedofficers and men that this was best
column4: and they went to work on thedefences and approaches with a will.  With the navy holding the river
column5: the investment of Vicksburg was complete.  As long as we could hold ourposition the enemy was limited in supplies of food
column6: men and munitions ofwar to what they had on hand.  These could not last always.The crossing of troops at Bruinsburg commenced April 30th.  On the 18thof May the army was in rear of Vicksburg.  On the 19th
column7: just twenty daysafter the crossing
column8: the city was completely invested and an assault hadbeen made:  five distinct battles (besides continuous skirmishing) hadbeen fought and won by the Union forces; the capital of the State hadfallen and its arsenals
column9: military manufactories and everything usefulfor military purposes had been destroyed; an average of about onehundred and eighty miles had been marched by the troops engaged; butfive days' rations had been issued
column10: and no forage; over six thousandprisoners had been captured
column11: and as many more of the enemy had beenkilled or wounded; twenty-seven heavy cannon and sixty-one field-pieceshad fallen into our hands; and four hundred miles of the river
column12: fromVicksburg to Port Hudson
column13: had become ours.  The Union force that hadcrossed the Mississippi River up to this time was less than forty-threethousand men. One division of these
column14: Blair's
column15: only arrived in time totake part in the battle of Champion's Hill
column16: but was not engaged there;and one brigade
column17: Ransom's of McPherson's corps
column18: reached the field afterthe battle.  The enemy had at Vicksburg
column19: Grand Gulf
column20: Jackson
column21: and on theroads between these places
column22: over sixty thousand men.  They were in theirown country
column23: where no rear guards were necessary.  The country isadmirable for defence
column24: but difficult for the conduct of an offensivecampaign.  All their troops had to be met.  We were fortunate
column25: to saythe least
column26: in meeting them in detail:  at Port Gibson seven or eightthousand; at Raymond
column27: five thousand; at Jackson
column28: from eight to eleventhousand; at Champion's Hill
column29: twenty-five thousand; at the Big Black
column30: four thousand.  A part of those met at Jackson were all that was left ofthose encountered at Raymond.  They were beaten in detail by a forcesmaller than their own
column31: upon their own ground.  Our loss up to this timewas:                             KILLED  WOUNDED  MISSING Port Gibson.....              131     719      25 South Fork Bayou Pierre.....   ..       1      .. Skirmishes
column32: May 3 .....         1       9      .. Fourteen Mile Creek.....        6      24      .. Raymond...............         66     339      39 Jackson.....                   42     251       7 Champion's Hill.....          410   1
column34: 425     259Of the wounded many were but slightly so
column35: and continued on duty.  Nothalf of them were disabled for any length of time.After the unsuccessful assault of the 22d the work of the regular siegebegan.  Sherman occupied the right starting from the river aboveVicksburg
column36: McPherson the centre (McArthur's division now with him) andMcClernand the left
column37: holding the road south to Warrenton.  Lauman'sdivision arrived at this time and was placed on the extreme left of theline.In the interval between the assaults of the 19th and 22d
column38: roads had beencompleted from the Yazoo River and Chickasaw Bayou
column39: around the rear ofthe army
column40: to enable us to bring up supplies of food and ammunition;ground had been selected and cleared on which the troops were to beencamped
column41: and tents and cooking utensils were brought up.  The troopshad been without these from the time of crossing the Mississippi up tothis time.  All was now ready for the pick and spade.  Prentiss andHurlbut were ordered to send forward every man that could be spared.Cavalry especially was wanted to watch the fords along the Big Black
column42: and to observe Johnston.  I knew that Johnston was receivingreinforcements from Bragg
column43: who was confronting Rosecrans in Tennessee.Vicksburg was so important to the enemy that I believed he would makethe most strenuous efforts to raise the siege
column44: even at the risk oflosing ground elsewhere.My line was more than fifteen miles long
column45: extending from Haines' Bluffto Vicksburg
column46: thence to Warrenton.  The line of the enemy was aboutseven.  In addition to this
column47: having an enemy at Canton and Jackson
column48: inour rear
column49: who was being constantly reinforced
column50: we required a second lineof defence facing the other way.  I had not troops enough under mycommand to man these.  General Halleck appreciated the situation and
column51: without being asked
column52: forwarded reinforcements with all possibledispatch.The ground about Vicksburg is admirable for defence.  On the north it isabout two hundred feet above the Mississippi River at the highest pointand very much cut up by the washing rains; the ravines were grown upwith cane and underbrush
column53: while the sides and tops were covered with adense forest.  Farther south the ground flattens out somewhat
column54: and wasin cultivation.  But here
column55: too
column56: it was cut up by ravines and smallstreams.  The enemy's line of defence followed the crest of a ridge fromthe river north of the city eastward
column57: then southerly around to theJackson road
column58: full three miles back of the city; thence in asouthwesterly direction to the river.  Deep ravines of the descriptiongiven lay in front of these defences.  As there is a succession ofgullies
column59: cut out by rains along the side of the ridge
column60: the line wasnecessarily very irregular.  To follow each of these spurs withintrenchments
column61: so as to command the slopes on either side
column62: would havelengthened their line very much. Generally therefore
column63: or in many places
column64: their line would run from near the head of one gully nearly straight tothe head of another
column65: and an outer work triangular in shape
column66: generallyopen in the rear
column67: was thrown up on the point; with a few men in thisouter work they commanded the approaches to the main line completely.The work to be done
column68: to make our position as strong against the enemy ashis was against us
column69: was very great.  The problem was also complicated byour wanting our line as near that of the enemy as possible.  We had butfour engineer officers with us. Captain Prime
column70: of the Engineer Corps
column71: was the chief
column72: and the work at the beginning was mainly directed by him.His health soon gave out
column73: when he was succeeded by Captain Comstock
column74: also of the Engineer Corps.  To provide assistants on such a long line Idirected that all officers who had graduated at West Point
column75: where theyhad necessarily to study military engineering
column76: should in addition totheir other duties assist in the work.The chief quartermaster and the chief commissary were graduates.  Thechief commissary
column77: now the Commissary-General of the Army
column78: begged off
column79: however
column80: saying that there was nothing in engineering that he was goodfor unless he would do for a sap-roller.  As soldiers require rationswhile working in the ditches as well as when marching and fighting
column81: andas we would be sure to lose him if he was used as a sap-roller
column82: I lethim off.  The general is a large man; weighs two hundred and twentypounds
column83: and is not tall.We had no siege guns except six thirty-two pounders
column84: and there were noneat the West to draw from.  Admiral Porter
column85: however
column86: supplied us with abattery of navy-guns of large calibre
column87: and with these
column88: and the fieldartillery used in the campaign
column89: the siege began.  The first thing to dowas to get the artillery in batteries where they would occupy commandingpositions; then establish the camps
column90: under cover from the fire of theenemy but as near up as possible; and then construct rifle-pits andcovered ways
column91: to connect the entire command by the shortest route.  Theenemy did not harass us much while we were constructing our batteries.Probably their artillery ammunition was short; and their infantry waskept down by our sharpshooters
column92: who were always on the alert and readyto fire at a head whenever it showed itself above the rebel works.In no place were our lines more than six hundred yards from the enemy.It was necessary
column93: therefore
column94: to cover our men by something more thanthe ordinary parapet.  To give additional protection sand bags
column95: bullet-proof
column96: were placed along the tops of the parapets far enoughapart to make loop-holes for musketry.  On top of these
column97: logs were put.By these means the men were enabled to walk about erect when off duty
column98: without fear of annoyance from sharpshooters.  The enemy used in theirdefence explosive musket-balls
column99: no doubt thinking that
column100: bursting overour men in the trenches
column101: they would do some execution; but I do notremember a single case where a man was injured by a piece of one ofthese shells. When they were hit and the ball exploded
column102: the wound wasterrible.  In these cases a solid ball would have hit as well.  Theiruse is barbarous
column103: because they produce increased suffering without anycorresponding advantage to those using them.The enemy could not resort to our method to protect their men
column104: becausewe had an inexhaustible supply of ammunition to draw upon and used itfreely.  Splinters from the timber would have made havoc among the menbehind.There were no mortars with the besiegers
column105: except what the navy had infront of the city; but wooden ones were made by taking logs of thetoughest wood that could be found
column106: boring them out for six or twelvepound shells and binding them with strong iron bands.  These answered ascochorns
column107: and shells were successfully thrown from them into thetrenches of the enemy.The labor of building the batteries and intrenching was largely done bythe pioneers
column108: assisted by negroes who came within our lines and who werepaid for their work; but details from the troops had often to be made.The work was pushed forward as rapidly as possible
column109: and when an advancedposition was secured and covered from the fire of the enemy thebatteries were advanced.  By the 30th of June there were two hundred andtwenty guns in position
column110: mostly light field-pieces
column111: besides a battery ofheavy guns belonging to
column112: manned and commanded by the navy.  We were nowas strong for defence against the garrison of Vicksburg as they wereagainst us; but I knew that Johnston was in our rear
column113: and was receivingconstant reinforcements from the east. He had at this time a largerforce than I had had at any time prior to the battle of Champion's Hill.As soon as the news of the arrival of the Union army behind Vicksburgreached the North
column114: floods of visitors began to pour in.  Some came togratify curiosity; some to see sons or brothers who had passed throughthe terrible ordeal; members of the Christian and Sanitary Associationscame to minister to the wants of the sick and the wounded.  Often thosecoming to see a son or brother would bring a dozen or two of poultry.They did not know how little the gift would be appreciated.  Many of thesoldiers had lived so much on chickens
column115: ducks and turkeys without breadduring the march
column116: that the sight of poultry
column117: if they could get bacon
column118: almost took away their appetite.  But the intention was good.Among the earliest arrivals was the Governor of Illinois
column119: with most ofthe State officers.  I naturally wanted to show them what there was ofmost interest.  In Sherman's front the ground was the most broken andmost wooded
column120: and more was to be seen without exposure.  I therefore tookthem to Sherman's headquarters and presented them.  Before starting outto look at the lines--possibly while Sherman's horse was being saddled--there were many questions asked about the late campaign
column121: about whichthe North had been so imperfectly informed.  There was a little knotaround Sherman and another around me
column122: and I heard Sherman repeating
column123: inthe most animated manner
column124: what he had said to me when we first lookeddown from Walnut Hills upon the land below on the 18th of May
column125: adding:'Grant is entitled to every bit of the credit for the campaign; Iopposed it. I wrote him a letter about it.'  But for this speech it isnot likely that Sherman's opposition would have ever been heard of.  Hisuntiring energy and great efficiency during the campaign entitle him toa full share of all the credit due for its success.  He could not havedone more if the plan had been his own. (*13)On the 26th of May I sent Blair's division up the Yazoo to drive out aforce of the enemy supposed to be between the Big Black and the Yazoo.The country was rich and full of supplies of both food and forage.Blair was instructed to take all of it.  The cattle were to be driven infor the use of our army
column126: and the food and forage to be consumed by ourtroops or destroyed by fire; all bridges were to be destroyed
column127: and theroads rendered as nearly impassable as possible.  Blair went forty-fivemiles and was gone almost a week.  His work was effectually done.  Irequested Porter at this time to send the marine brigade
column128: a floatingnondescript force which had been assigned to his command and whichproved very useful
column129: up to Haines' Bluff to hold it until reinforcementscould be sent.On the 26th I also received a letter from Banks
column130: asking me to reinforcehim with ten thousand men at Port Hudson.  Of course I could not complywith his request
column131: nor did I think he needed them.  He was in no dangerof an attack by the garrison in his front
column132: and there was no armyorganizing in his rear to raise the siege.On the 3d of June a brigade from Hurlbut's command arrived
column133: GeneralKimball commanding.  It was sent to Mechanicsburg
column134: some miles north-eastof Haines' Bluff and about midway between the Big Black and the Yazoo.A brigade of Blair's division and twelve hundred cavalry had already
column135: onBlair's return from the Yazoo
column136: been sent to the same place withinstructions to watch the crossings of the Big Black River
column137: to destroythe roads in his (Blair's) front
column138: and to gather or destroy all supplies.On the 7th of June our little force of colored and white troops acrossthe Mississippi
column139: at Milliken's Bend
column140: were attacked by about 3
column141: 000 menfrom Richard Taylor's trans-Mississippi command.  With the aid of thegunboats they were speedily repelled.  I sent Mower's brigade over withinstructions to drive the enemy beyond the Tensas Bayou; and we had nofurther trouble in that quarter during the siege.  This was the firstimportant engagement of the war in which colored troops were under fire.These men were very raw
column142: having all been enlisted since the beginning ofthe siege
column143: but they behaved well.On the 8th of June a full division arrived from Hurlbut's command
column144: underGeneral Sooy Smith.  It was sent immediately to Haines' Bluff
column145: andGeneral C. C. Washburn was assigned to the general command at thatpoint.On the 11th a strong division arrived from the Department of theMissouri under General Herron
column146: which was placed on our left. This cutoff the last possible chance of communication between Pemberton andJohnston
