column54: to tryto get under the cover of our navy for protection against the Southernpeople.  As the army was seen marching on triumphantly
column55: however
column56: theminds of the people became disabused and they saw the true state ofaffairs.  In turn they became disheartened
column57: and would have been glad tosubmit without compromise.Another great advantage resulting from this march
column58: and which wascalculated to hasten the end
column59: was the fact that the great storehouse ofGeorgia was entirely cut off from the Confederate armies.  As the troopsadvanced north from Savannah
column60: the destruction of the railroads in SouthCarolina and the southern part of North Carolina
column61: further cut off theirresources and left the armies still in Virginia and North Carolinadependent for supplies upon a very small area of country
column62: already verymuch exhausted of food and forage.In due time the two armies
column63: one from Burkesville Junction and the otherfrom the neighborhood of Raleigh
column64: North Carolina
column65: arrived and went intocamp near the Capital
column66: as directed.  The troops were hardy
column67: being inuredto fatigue
column68: and they appeared in their respective camps as ready and fitfor duty as they had ever been in their lives.  I doubt whether an equalbody of men of any nation
column69: take them man for man
column70: officer for officer
column71: was ever gotten together that would have proved their equal in a greatbattle.The armies of Europe are machines; the men are brave and the officerscapable; but the majority of the soldiers in most of the nations ofEurope are taken from a class of people who are not very intelligent andwho have very little interest in the contest in which they are calledupon to take part.  Our armies were composed of men who were able toread
column72: men who knew what they were fighting for
column73: and could not be inducedto serve as soldiers
column74: except in an emergency when the safety of thenation was involved
column75: and so necessarily must have been more than equalto men who fought merely because they were brave and because they werethoroughly drilled and inured to hardships.There was nothing of particular importance occurred during the timethese troops were in camp before starting North.I remember one little incident which I will relate as an anecdotecharacteristic of Mr. Lincoln.  It occurred a day after I reachedWashington
column76: and about the time General Meade reached Burkesville withthe army.  Governor Smith of Virginia had left Richmond with theConfederate States government
column77: and had gone to Danville.  Supposing Iwas necessarily with the army at Burkesville
column78: he addressed a letter tome there informing me that
column79: as governor of the Commonwealth of the Stateof Virginia
column80: he had temporarily removed the State capital from Richmondto Danville
column81: and asking if he would be permitted to perform thefunctions of his office there without molestation by the Federalauthorities.  I give this letter only in substance.  He also inquired ofme whether in case he was not allowed to perform the duties of hisoffice
column82: he with a few others might not be permitted to leave the countryand go abroad without interference.  General Meade being informed that aflag of truce was outside his pickets with a letter to me
column83: at once sentout and had the letter brought in without informing the officer whobrought it that I was not present.  He read the letter and telegraphedme its contents. Meeting Mr. Lincoln shortly after receiving thisdispatch
column84: I repeated its contents to him.  Mr. Lincoln
column85: supposing I wasasking for instructions
column86: said
column87: in reply to that part of Governor Smith'sletter which inquired whether he with a few friends would be permittedto leave the country unmolested
column88: that his position was like that of acertain Irishman (giving the name) he knew in Springfield who was verypopular with the people
column89: a man of considerable promise

column1: ENTP	 and his successors.  What follows          was written in the last year of Dr. 's life

column3: I went to visit Dr. Fothergill
column4: to whom I was strongly recommended
column5: and whose counsel respecting my proceedings I was advis'd to obtain.He was against an immediate complaint to government
column6: and thoughtthe proprietaries should first be personally appli'd to
column7: who mightpossibly be induc'd by the interposition and persuasion of someprivate friends
column8: to accommodate matters amicably.  I then waitedon my old friend and correspondent
column9: Mr. Peter Collinson
column10: who toldme that John Hanbury
column11: the great Virginia merchant
column12: had requestedto be informed when I should arrive
column13: that he might carry me to LordGranville's
column14: who was then President of the Council and wished to seeme as soon as possible.  I agreed to go with him the next morning.Accordingly Mr. Hanbury called for me and took me in his carriageto that nobleman's
column15: who receiv'd me with great civility; and aftersome questions respecting the present state of affairs in Americaand discourse thereupon
column16: he said to me:  'You Americans have wrongideas of the nature of your constitution; you contend that the king'sinstructions to his governors are not laws
column17: and think yourselvesat liberty to regard or disregard them at your own discretion.But those instructions are not like the pocket instructions givento a minister going abroad
column18: for regulating his conduct in sometrifling point of ceremony.  They are first drawn up by judgeslearned in the laws; they are then considered
column19: debated
column20: and perhapsamended in Council
column21: after which they are signed by the king.They are then
column22: so far as they relate to you
column23: the law of the land
column24: for the king is the LEGISLATOR OF THE COLONIES.'  I told hislordship this was new doctrine to me.  I had always understoodfrom our charters that our laws were to be made by our Assemblies
column25: to be presented indeed to the king for his royal assent
column26: but that being once given the king could not repeal or alter them.And as the Assemblies could not make permanent laws withouthis assent
column27: so neither could he make a law for them without theirs.He assur'd me I was totally mistaken.  I did not think so
column28: however
column29: and his lordship's conversation having a little alarm'd me as towhat might be the sentiments of the court concerning us
column30: I wroteit down as soon as I return'd to my lodgings.  I recollected thatabout 20 years before
column31: a clause in a bill brought into Parliamentby the ministry had propos'd to make the king's instructions lawsin the colonies
column32: but the clause was thrown out by the Commons
column33: for which we adored them as our friends and friends of liberty
column34: till by their conduct towards us in 1765 it seem'd that they hadrefus'd that point of sovereignty to the king only that they mightreserve it for themselves.After some days
column35: Dr. Fothergill having spoken to the proprietaries
column36: they agreed to a meeting with me at Mr. T. Penn's house in Spring Garden.The conversation at first consisted of mutual declarationsof disposition to reasonable accommodations
column37: but I suppose eachparty had its own ideas of what should be meant by reasonable.We then went into consideration of our several points of complaint
column38: which I enumerated.  The proprietaries justify'd their conductas well as they could
column39: and I the Assembly's. We now appearedvery wide
column40: and so far from each other in our opinions as todiscourage all hope of agreement.  However
column41: it was concludedthat I should give them the heads of our complaints in writing
column42: and they promis'd then to consider them.  I did so soon after
column43: but they put the paper into the hands of their solicitor
column44: Ferdinand John Paris
column45: who managed for them all their law businessin their great suit with the neighbouring proprietary of Maryland

column47: which had subsisted 70 years
column48: and wrote for themall their papers and messages in their dispute with the Assembly.He was a proud
column49: angry man
column50: and as I had occasionally in the answersof the Assembly treated his papers with some severity
column51: they beingreally weak in point of argument and haughty in expression
column52: he had conceived a mortal enmity to me
column53: which discovering itselfwhenever we met
column54: I declin'd the proprietary's proposal that heand I should discuss the heads of complaint between our two selves
column55: and refus'd treating with any one but them.  They then by his adviceput the paper into the hands of the Attorney and Solicitor-Generalfor their opinion and counsel upon it
column56: where it lay unanswereda year wanting eight days
column57: during which time I made frequent demandsof an answer from the proprietaries
column58: but without obtaining any otherthan that they had not yet received the opinion of the Attorneyand Solicitor-General.  What it was when they did receive it Inever learnt
column59: for they did not communicate it to me
column60: but sent a longmessage to the Assembly drawn and signed by Paris
column61: reciting my paper
column62: complaining of its want of formality
column63: as a rudeness on my part
column64: and giving a flimsy justification of their conduct
column65: adding that theyshould be willing to accommodate matters if the Assembly would sendout some person of candour to treat with them for that purpose
column66: intimating thereby that I was not such.The want of formality or rudeness was
column67: probably
column68: my not havingaddress'd the paper to them with their assum'd titles of Trueand Absolute Proprietaries of the Province of Pennsylvania
column69: which I omitted as not thinking it necessary in a paper
column70: the intention of which was only to reduce to a certainty by writing
column71: what in conversation I had delivered viva voce.But during this delay

column73: which was the grand point in dispute
column74: they omitted answering the message.When this act however came over
column75: the proprietaries
column76: counselledby Paris
column77: determined to oppose its receiving the royal assent.Accordingly they petition'd the king in Council

column100: and beckoning metook me into the clerk's chamber

column1: ESTP	 ITHE UGANDA RAILWAYThe aspect of Mombasa as she rises from the sea and clothes herselfwith form and colour at the swift approach of the ship is alluring andeven delicious. But to appreciate all these charms the travellershould come from the North. He should see the hot stones of Malta
column2: baking and glistening on a steel-blue Mediterranean. He should visitthe Island of Cyprus before the autumn rains have revived the soil
column3: when the Messaoria Plain is one broad wilderness of dust
column4: when everytree--be it only a thorn-bush--is an heirloom
column5: and every drop of wateris a jewel. He should walk for two hours at midday in the streets ofPort Said. He should thread the long red furrow of the Suez Canal
column6: andswelter through the trough of the Red Sea. He should pass a day amongthe cinders of Aden
column7: and a week among the scorched rocks and stones ofNorthern Somaliland; and then
column8: after five days of open sea
column9: his eyeand mind will be prepared to salute with feelings of grateful delightthese shores of vivid and exuberant green. On every side isvegetation
column10: moist
column11: tumultuous
column12: and varied. Great trees
column13: clad in densefoliage
column14: shrouded in creepers
column15: springing from beds of verdure
column16: thrustthemselves through the undergrowth; palms laced together by floweringtrailers; every kind of tropical plant that lives by rain andsunshine; high waving grass
column17: brilliant patches of purplebougainvillea
column18: and in the midst
column19: dotted about
column20: scarcely keeping theirheads above the fertile flood of Nature
column21: the red-roofed houses of thetown and port of Mombasa.  [Illustration: SKETCH MAP OF    'MY AFRICAN JOURNEY']The vessel follows a channel twisting away between high bluffs
column22: andfinds a secure anchorage
column23: land-locked
column24: in forty feet of water at astone's throw from the shore. Here we are arrived at the gate ofBritish East Africa; and more
column25: at the outlet and debouchment of allthe trade of all the countries that lap the Victoria and Albert Lakesand the head-waters of the Nile. Along the pier now being built atKilindini
column26: the harbour of Mombasa Island
column27: must flow
column28: at any rate formany years
column29: the main stream of East and Central African commerce.Whatever may be the produce which civilized government and enterprisewill draw from the enormous territories between Southern Abyssinia andLake Tanganyika
column30: between Lake Rudolf and Ruenzori
column31: as far west as thehead-streams of the Congo
column32: as far north as the Lado enclave; whatevermay be the needs and demands of the numerous populations comprisedwithin those limits
column33: it is along the unpretentious jetty of Kilindinithat the whole traffic must pass.For Kilindini (or Mombasa
column34: as I may be permitted to call it) is thestarting-point of one of the most romantic and most wonderful railwaysin the world. The two iron streaks of rail that wind away among thehills and foliage of Mombasa Island do not break their smooth monotonyuntil
column35: after piercing Equatorial forests
column36: stretching across immenseprairies
column37: and climbing almost to the level of the European snow-line
column38: they pause--and that only for a time--upon the edges of the GreatLake. And thus is made a sure
column39: swift road along which the white manand all that he brings with him
column40: for good or ill
column41: may penetrate intothe heart of Africa as easily and safely as he may travel from Londonto Vienna.Short has been the life
column42: many the vicissitudes
column43: of the Uganda Railway.The adventurous enterprise of a Liberal Government
column44: it was soonexposed
column45: disowned
column46: to the merciless criticism of its parents. Adoptedas a cherished foundling by the Conservative party
column47: it almost perishedfrom mismanagement in their hands. Nearly ten thousand pounds a milewere expended upon its construction; and so eager were all parties tobe done with it and its expense that
column48: instead of pursuing its properand natural route across the plateau to the deep waters of PortVictoria
column49: it fell by the way into the shallow gulf of Kavirondo
column50: luckyto get so far. It is easy to censure
column51: it is impossible not tocriticize
column52: the administrative mistakes and miscalculations whichtarnished and nearly marred a brilliant conception. But it is stillmore easy
column53: as one traverses in forty-eight hours countries which tenyears ago would have baffled the toilsome marches of many weeks
column54: tounderrate the difficulties in which unavoidable ignorance andastonishing conditions plunged the pioneers. The British art of'muddling through' is here seen in one of its finest expositions.Through everything--through the forests
column55: through the ravines
column56: throughtroops of marauding lions
column57: through famine
column58: through war
column59: through fiveyears of excoriating Parliamentary debate
column60: muddled and marched therailway; and here at last
column61: in some more or less effective fashion
column62: isit arrived at its goal. Other nations project Central African railwaysas lightly and as easily as they lay down naval programmes; but hereis a railway
column63: like the British Fleet
column64: 'in being'--not a paper plan oran airy dream
column65: but an iron fact grinding along through the jungle andthe plain
column66: waking with its whistles the silences of the Nyanza
column67: andstartling the tribes out of their primordial nakedness with'Americani' piece goods _made in Lancashire_.Let us
column68: then
column69: without waiting in Mombasa longer than is necessary towish it well and to admire the fertility and promise of the coastalregion
column70: ascend this railway from the sea to the lake. And first
column71: whata road it is! Everything is in apple-pie order. The track is smoothedand weeded and ballasted as if it were the London and North-Western.Every telegraph-post has its number; every mile
column72: every hundred yards
column73: every change of gradient has its mark; not in soft wood
column74: to feed thewhite ant

column231: the greatest in this part of the country
column232: hadorganized an imposing demonstration. In dense array they lined theroad from the station to the Commissioner's house
column233: and our partywalked through their midst in a perfect hubbub of horns and drums andshrill salutations. All the warriors carried their spears
column234: shields
column235: and war-paint
column236: and most of them wore splendid plumes of ostrichfeathers. The Kavirondo are naked and unashamed. Both sexes areaccustomed to walk about in the primitive simplicity of Nature. Theirnudity is based not upon mere ignorance but reasoned policy. They havea very strong prejudice against the wearing of clothes
column237: which theydeclare lead to immorality; and no Kavirondo woman can attire herselfeven in the most exiguous raiment without sullying her reputation.They are said to be the most moral of all the tribes dwelling on theLake shore. It is a pity that Herr Diogenes Teufelsdrckh
column238: of theUniversity of Weissnichtwo
column239: did not meet them in his ruggedwanderings
column240: for they would surely have enabled him to add another pageto his monumental work on the functions of the tailor.  [Illustration: NANDI AND KAVIRONDO WARRIORS AT KISUMU.]I wake up the next morning to find myself afloat on a magnificentship. Its long and spacious decks are as snowy as those of a pleasureyacht. It is equipped with baths
column241: electric light
column242: and all modernnecessities. There is an excellent table
column243: also a well-selectedlibrary. Smart bluejackets--with ebon faces--are polishing thebrasswork; dapper
column244: white-clad British naval officers pace the bridge.We are steaming ten miles an hour across an immense sea of fresh wateras big as Scotland
column245: and uplifted higher than the summit of Ben Nevis.At times we are in a complete circle of lake and sky
column246: without a signof land. At others we skirt lofty coasts covered with forest andcrowned with distant blue-brown mountains
column247: or thread our coursebetween a multitude of beautiful islands. The air is cool and fresh
column248: the scenery splendid. We might be yachting off the coast of Cornwallin July. We are upon the Equator
column250: and crossingthe Victoria Nyanza
column251: four thousand feet above the sea!

column1: ESTP	 VTHE KINGDOM OF UGANDAThe East Africa Protectorate is a country of the highest interest tothe colonist
column2: the traveller
column3: or the sportsman. But the Kingdom ofUganda is a fairy tale. You climb up a railway instead of a beanstalk

column6: the climate is different
column7: and
column8: most of all

column10: painted savages

column14: and a powerful feudal system
column15: an amiable
column16: clothed
column17: polite

column21: thereis industry
column22: there is culture

An elaborate ritual of friendly salutationsrelieves the monotony of the wayfarer's journey. Submission withoutservility or loss of self-respect is accorded to constitutedauthority. The natives evince an eagerness to acquire knowledge and avery high observant and imitative faculty. And then Uganda is from endto end one beautiful garden

column67: has carried us smoothly and prosperously across the northerncorner of the Victoria Nyanza
column68: and reaches the pier of Entebbe as theafternoon draws towards its close. The first impression that strikesthe eye of the visitor fresh from Kavirondo is the spectacle ofhundreds of natives all dressed in long clean white garments whichthey wear with dignity and ease. At the landing-place a sort ofpavilion has been erected

column72: purple
column73: yellow
column74: and crimson blossoms

Yet what istrue of the East Africa Protectorate is even more true of Uganda. Thecontrast between appearance and reality is more striking and moreharsh. Behind its glittering mask Entebbe wears a sinister aspect.These smiling islands which adorn and diversify the scenery of thelake supported a few years ago a large population. To-day they aredesolate. Every white man seems to feel a sense of undefinableoppression. A cut will not heal; a scratch festers. In the thirdyear of residence even a small wound becomes a running sore. One day aman feels perfectly well; the next

column79: he isprostrate with malaria

column88: ENTEBBE.]There are many who advocate the abandonment of Entebbe as theadministrative capital and the restoration of the seat of Governmentto Kampala. But the expense of transferring public offices andbuildings lately erected to another site is altogether beyond theslender resources and not among the most urgent needs of the UgandaProtectorate. Great improvements have been effected recently in thesanitation of Entebbe. The bush and trees

column93: the general unhealthiness of the country so far as theEuropean is concerned is not local to Entebbe. It is widely spread inslightly different degrees throughout the whole of Uganda; and Kampalais certainly not exempt. Finally
column94: there is a reason of a differentcharacter which ought to impose a final bar on any return of theImperial Government to the native city. Uganda is a native state. Muchof our success in dealing with its population arises from the factthat we work through and by the native Government. And that Governmentcould not fail to lose much

column116: the British power in these regionsis at present beyond challenge. No man can withstand it. But a newopponent has appeared and will not be denied. Uganda is defended byits insects. It would even seem that the arrival of the white man andthe increased movement and activity which his presence has engenderedhave awakened these formidable atoms to a realization of their powersof evil. The dreaded _Spirillum_ tick has begun to infest the roadslike a tiny footpad
column117: and scarcely any precautions avail with certaintyagainst him. This tick is a dirty
column118: drab-coloured creature the size andshape of a small squashed pea. When he bites an infected person hedoes not contract the Spirillum fever himself
column119: nor does he transmit itdirectly to other persons. By a peculiarly malevolent provision ofNature this power is exercised not by him but by his descendants
column120: whoare numbered in hundreds. So the poison spreads in an incalculableprogression. Although this fever is not fatal
column121: it is exceptionallypainful in its course and distressing in its consequences. There arefive or six separate and successive attacks of fever
column122: in which thetemperature of the victim may rise even to 107 degrees; andafterwards the eyes and hearing are temporarily affected by a kind offacial paralysis. Road after road has been declared infected by thisscourge
column123: and officer after officer struck down as he moves on dutyfrom place to place. The only sure preventive seems to be thedestruction of all old grass-huts and camping-grounds
column124: and theerection along the roads of a regular system of stone-built
column125: properlymaintained and disinfected rest-houses
column126: in which the traveller maytake refuge from the lurking peril. And this will have to be done.But a far more terrible shadow darkens the Uganda Protectorate. InJuly
column128: a doctor of the Church Missionary Society Hospital atKampala noticed eight cases of a mysterious disease. Six months laterhe reported that over two hundred natives had died of it in the Islandof Buvuma
column129: and that thousands appeared to be infected. The pestilenceswiftly spread through all the districts of the lake shore
column130: and themortality was appalling. No one could tell where it had come from orwhat it was caused by. It resisted every kind of treatment andappeared to be universally fatal. Scientific inquiries of variouskinds were immediately set on foot
column131: but for a long time no resultswere obtained
column132: and meanwhile the disease ran along the coasts andislands of the great lake like fire in a high wind. By the middle of1902 the reported deaths from _Trypanosomiasis_
column133: or 'sleepingsickness
column134: ' as it has come to be called
column135: numbered over thirty thousand.It was still spreading rapidly upon all sides
column136: and no clue whatever toits treatment or prevention had been obtained. It seemed certain thatthe entire population of the districts affected was doomed.On April 28th
column138: Colonel Bruce
column139: whose services had been obtainedfor the investigation of 'sleeping sickness' through theinstrumentality of the Royal Society

column142: and was rarelyfound to extend more than a mile or two from water. The news thatEuropeans could no longer consider themselves immune from theinfection caused
column143: as might be imagined
column144: much consternation in thewhite community. Nearly everybody had been bitten by tsetses at onetime or another
column145: but whether by this particular species when actuallyinfected

column147: tsetse-flies abounded insuch numbers on all parts of the lake shore that their wholesaledestruction seemed quite impossible. What then?For a time Colonel Bruce's discovery almost paralyzed all preventiveand restrictive measures. The scourge fell unchecked. By the end of1903 the reported deaths numbered over ninety thousand
column148: and the lakeshores were becoming fast depopulated. Whole villages were completelyexterminated

column153: thedying
column154: and the dead.Further investigations

The Albert shores andseveral parts of the Upper Nile soon became new centres of pestilence.Thousands of deaths occurred in Unyoro. By the end of 1905considerably more than two hundred thousand persons had perished inthe plague-stricken regions

column23: ' cry thepushers; 'Huma

column43: 'Thehonour is mine

[Illustration: ON THE WAY TO KAMPALA.]  [Illustration: ROAD BETWEEN JINJA AND LAKE CHIOGA.]The incident is remarkable because it illustrates the rapidity withwhich the Baganda people are leaving their past behind them. Alreadythey laugh at their old selves. Ceremonies which twenty years ago hada solemn and awful significance

column137: and the Prime Ministerwas making a speech to explain that this was meant to be a pageant ofthe bad old times reproduced for our benefit. Indeed
column138: so unaccustomedto carry arms had the warriors become that not one in ten could find aspear to arm himself with

I have described how Kampalalies under the leaves of the plantain groves about the slopes of manyhills. Each hill has its special occupants and purpose. Each of thedifferent Christian missions has a hill to itself
column157: and in the bad olddays a Maxim gun was not thought at all an inappropriate aid toChristian endeavour. It would
column158: however
column159: be very unfair to charge themissionaries with having created the feuds and struggles whichconvulsed Uganda twelve years ago. The accident that the line ofcleavage between French and British influence was also the line ofcleavage between Catholic and Protestant converts
column160: imparted areligious complexion to what was in reality a fierce politicaldispute. These troubles are now definitely at an end. The arrival uponthe scene of an English Catholic mission has prevented nationalrivalries and religious differences from mutually embittering oneanother. The erection of a stable Government and the removal of alldoubts about the future of Uganda have led to an entire abatement ofstrife among devoted men engaged in a noble work. Not only is therepeace among the different Christian missions themselves
column161: but theGovernment of Uganda
column162: so far from watching missionary enterprise withsour disfavour
column163: is thoroughly alive to the inestimable services whichhave been and are daily being rendered by the missions to the nativepopulation
column164: and excellent relations prevail.  [Illustration: THE WHITE FATHERS' MISSION AT KAMPALA.]  [Illustration: CHILDREN AT THE ENGLISH CATHOLIC MISSION
column165: KAMPALA.]In duty bound I climbed one hill after another and endeavoured to makemyself acquainted with the details of mission work in Kampala. Itcomprises every form of moral and social activity. Apart from theirspiritual work
column166: which needs no advocacy here
column167: the missionaries haveundertaken and are now maintaining the whole educational system of thecountry. They have built many excellent schools
column168: and thousands ofyoung Baganda are being taught to read and write in their ownlanguage. The whole country is dotted with subsidiary missionstations
column169: each one a centre of philanthropic and Christian effort.There are good hospitals
column170: with skilful doctors and nurses or sistersof charity
column171: in connection with all the missions. The largest of these
column172: belonging to the Church Missionary Society
column173: is a model of what atropical hospital for natives ought to be. Technical education is nowbeing added to these services
column174: and in this
column175: it is to be hoped
column176: theGovernment will be able to cooperate. I do not know of any other partof the world where missionary influence and enterprise have been sobeneficently exerted
column177: or where more valuable results have beenachieved.On Namirembe Hill
column178: where the Church Missionary Society have theirhead-quarters
column180: with three tall
column181: quaint
column183: has been built out of very primitive materials; andthis is almost the only building in Uganda which offers the slightestattempt at architectural display. Under the shadow of this I foundmyself on the afternoon of the 20th of November engaged in opening ahigh school for scholars who are more advanced than can be instructedin the existing establishments. A large and well-dressed audience
column184: native and European
column185: filled a good-sized room. The scholars crowdedtogether in a solid mass of white-dressed youths upon the floor. TheKabaka and Sir Apolo Kagwar
column186: who has himself five sons at the school

It was astonishing to look at the map of the BritishEmpire hanging on the wall and to realize that all this was takingplace near the north-western corner of the Victoria Nyanza.  [Illustration: INTERIOR OF NAMIREMBE CATHEDRAL.]It is eight miles from Kampala to Munyonyo

column199: and in the evening thelights of Jinja guided us to our destination. One cannot help admiringthe luck which led Speke to his thrilling discovery of the source ofthe Nile. There are five hundred gulfs and inlets on the northernshore of Lake Victoria
column200: and nothing distinguishes this one from therest. No current is perceptible to the ordinary mariner until within afew miles of the rapids

Instead of which he drifted and paddledgently along until all of a sudden the murmur of a distant cataractand the slight acceleration in the pace of his canoe drew him to thelong-sought birthplace of the most wonderful river in the world.It was dark when we landed at Jinja
column203: and I could not properly see thepreparations made for our reception by the local chiefs and the Indiantraders
column204: of whom there was a considerable crowd. The darkness

I am not quite sure that in all parts ofAfrica so high a standard of honour and respect for the life of thehumble native would prevail.Jinja is destined to become a very important place in the futureeconomy of Central Africa. Situated at the point where the Nile flowsout of the Great Lake
column213: it is at once on the easiest line of watercommunication with Lake Albert and the Soudan
column214: and also where greatwater-power is available. In years to come the shores of this splendidbay may be crowned with long rows of comfortable tropical villas andimposing offices
column215: and the gorge of the Nile crowded with factories andwarehouses. There is power enough to gin all the cotton and saw allthe wood in Uganda
column216: and it is here that one of the principal emporiaof tropical produce will certainly be created. In these circumstancesit is a pity to handicap the town with an outlandish name. It would bemuch better to call it Ripon Falls
column217: after the beautiful cascades whichlie beneath it
column218: and from whose force its future prosperity will bederived.The Ripon Falls are
column219: for their own sake

column221: a vast body of water nearly aswide as the Thames at Westminster Bridge
column222: and this imposing riverrushes down a stairway of rock from fifteen to twenty feet deep
column223: insmooth
column224: swirling slopes of green water. It would be perfectly easy toharness the whole river and let the Nile begin its long and beneficentjourney to the sea by leaping through a turbine. It is possible thatnowhere else in the world could so enormous a mass of water be held upby so little masonry. Two or three short dams from island to islandacross the falls would enable

column226: thewhole level of the Victoria Nyanza--over an expanse of a hundred andfifty thousand square miles--to be gradually raised six or seven feet;would greatly increase the available water-power; would deepen thewater in Kavirondo Bay
column227: so as to admit steamers of much largerdraught; and

column237: the problem of Uganda rises in a new form onthe mind. All this water-power belongs to the State. Ought it ever tobe surrendered to private persons? How long
column238: on the other hand
column239: is aGovernment
column240: if not prepared to act itself
column241: entitled to bar the way toothers? This question is raised in a multitude of diverse forms inalmost all the great dependencies of the Crown. But in Uganda thearguments for the State ownership and employment of the naturalresources of the country seem to present themselves in their strongestand most formidable array. Uganda is a native State. It must not becompared with any of those colonies where there is a white populationalready established
column242: nor again with those inhabited by tribes ofnomadic barbarians. It finds its counterparts among the great nativeStates of India
column243: where Imperial authority is exercised in the name andoften through the agency of a native prince and his own officers.This combination of the external brain and the native hand results ina form of government often highly acceptable to the general body ofthe inhabitants
column244: who are confronted with no sudden or arbitrarychanges in the long-accustomed appearances of things. But it involvesall the administration of affairs in a degree of complexity anddelicacy which is absent from simpler and cruder systems. In suchcircumstances there cannot be much opening for the push and drive ofordinary commercial enterprise. The hustling business man--admirablysuited to the rough and tumble of competitive production in Europe orAmerica--becomes an incongruous and even a dangerous figure whenintroduced into the smooth and leisurely development of a nativeState. The Baganda will not be benefited either morally or materiallyby contact with modern money-making or modern money-makers. When a manis working only for the profits of his company and is judged by thefinancial results alone
column245: he does not often under the sun of CentralAfrica acquire the best method of dealing with natives; and all sortsof difficulties and troubles will follow any sudden incursion ofbusiness enterprise into the forests and gardens of Uganda. And evenif the country is more rapidly developed by these agencies
column246: theprofits will not go to the Government and people of Uganda
column247: to be usedin fostering new industries
column248: but to divers persons across the sea
column250: other than purely commercial
column251: in its fortunes. Thisis not to advocate the arbitrary exclusion of private capital andenterprise from Uganda. Carefully directed and narrowly controlledopportunities for their activities will no doubt occur. But thenatural resources of the country should
column252: as far as possible
column253: bedeveloped by the Government itself
column254: even though that may involve theassumption of many new functions.Indeed
column255: it would be hard to find a country where the conditions weremore favourable than in Uganda to a practical experiment in StateSocialism. The land is rich; the people pacific and industrious. Thereare no great differences between class and class. One staple articleof food meets the needs of the whole population
column256: and produces itselfalmost without the aid of man. There are no European vested intereststo block the way. Nowhere are the powers of the Government toregulate and direct the activities of the people more overwhelming ormore comprehensive. The superiority of knowledge in the rulers iscommanding. Their control upon the natives is exerted through almostevery channel; and besides the secular authorities--native andImperial--there is the spiritual and educative influence of themissionaries to infuse human sympathy and moral earnestness into theregular machinery of State.The first
column257: and perhaps the greatest
column258: difficulty which confronts theEuropean Socialist is the choosing of Governors to whom the positivelyawful powers indispensable to a communistic society are to beentrusted. If a race of beings could be obtained when and as requiredfrom a neighbouring planet
column259: whose practical superiority in virtue
column260: science
column261: wisdom
column262: and strength was so manifest as to be universallyacclaimed
column263: this difficulty would disappear
column264: and we might withcomposure await the decision of popular elections with all theirdefects and advantages. But in the absence of this dispensation theproblem of how rulers are to be selected
column265: and how
column266: having beenselected
column267: they are to be controlled or changed
column268: remains the firstquestion of politics
column269: even in days when the functions of governmentare
column270: in general
column271: restricted to the modest limits of _laissez-faire_.In Uganda
column272: however
column273: this difficulty does not exist. A class of rulersis provided by an outside power as remote from and
column274: in all thatconstitutes fitness to direct
column275: as superior to the Baganda as Mr.Wells's Martians would have been to us. The British administration isin its _personnel_ absolutely disinterested. The officials draw theirsalaries
column276: and that is all. They have no end to serve
column277: except theimprovement of the country and the contentment of its people. By thattest and that test alone are they judged. In no other way can they winapprobation or fame. They are furthermore controlled in the exerciseof their functions by a superior authority
column278: specially instructed inthis class of administration
column279: and itself answerable to a Parliamentelected on a democratic franchise. At no point in the whole chain ofcommand is there any room for corruption
column280: usurpation
column281: or grossinefficiency.It is clear that larger powers could be entrusted to the State inregard to the labour of its citizens than would ever be accorded toprivate employers. The subjects of every European Power have acceptedthe obligation of military service to defend their respectivecountries from external attack. The Baganda
column282: relieved from this harshobsession
column283: have no higher duty than to cultivate and develop thebeautiful land they live in. And if it were desired to organizescientifically
column284: upon a humane and honourable basis
column286: and to apply the whole fruits of their labour totheir own enrichment and elevation
column287: no better conditions are likely tobe discovered than those which now exist in Uganda.It might at any rate be worth while to make such an experiment
column288: ifonly as a prelude to those more general applications of the principlesof Socialism which are held in some quarters to be so necessary.

Going on means going through.Everywhere great pathways are being cut into Africa. We have followedfor nearly a thousand miles one leading from the East towards thecentre. Far away from the North another line has been thrust forwardby British efforts in peace and war. From Alexandria to Cairo

column19: R.E.]The distance from the Victoria to the Albert Nyanza is about twohundred miles in the direct line

From thisvast elevated inland sea the descending Nile water flows through achannel of three thousand five hundred miles into the Mediterranean.The first and steepest stage of its journey is to the Albert Lake.This second body of water

So that in its first two hundred miles the Nile exhausts in theexuberant improvidence of youth about a third of the impulse which isto carry it through its venerable career. Yet this considerabledescent of twelve hundred feet is itself accomplished in two shortsteps. There is one series of rapids

column1: ESTP	 XITHE VICTORIA AND ALBERT RAILWAYMy journey is at an end
column2: the tale is told
column3: and the reader who hasfollowed so faithfully and so far has a right to ask what message Ibring back. It can be stated in three words. Concentrate upon Uganda!Over the greater part of the north-east quarter of Africa
column4: Britishinfluence or authority in one form or another is supreme. But when Iturn my mind over all those vast expanses
column5: excluding only Egypt
column6: thereis no region which offers prospects to compare in hopefulness withthose of the Protectorate of Uganda. The Soudan is far greater inextent and importance
column7: and Great Britain is at no charge in respect toit. But the Soudan is clearly inferior in fertility. The East AfricanProtectorate possesses not only enormous coast-lands of great value
column8: but noble plateaux where the air is as cool as an English spring. Butwe already spend on East Africa--and upon the needs of its expensivewhite settlers--more than the whole revenue of Uganda; and yet thepromise is not so bright. Northern Somaliland is a desert of rocks andthorn bushes peopled by rifle-armed fanatics
column9: on which we spend nearlyhalf as much as the whole annual grant-in-aid of Uganda. And betweenSomaliland and Uganda there is this contrast presented in its crudestform--a barren land with dangerous inhabitants; and a fruitful landwith a docile people. What is least worth having
column10: is most difficult tohold: what is most worth having
column11: is easiest.The union under scientific direction in Uganda (and I include in thispopular name Usoga
column12: Unyoro
column13: Toro and Ankole
column14: etc.) of unequalledfertility with a population of high intelligence and social quality
column15: in a region of extraordinary waterways
column16: must
column17: unless some grievouserror or neglect should intervene
column18: result in remarkable economicdevelopments. Already more than half the traffic which passes down therailway to Mombasa comes from beyond the lake. Yet scarcely any moneyhas ever been spent on Uganda. No European roads exist
column19: no railwayshave been built
column20: no waterfalls are harnessed
column21: no public works of anyserious description have been undertaken. A poor little grant-in-aidhas barely supported the day-to-day cost of European administration
column22: and practically nothing in cash or credit has been available for thedevelopment of the country. But it is alive by itself. It is vital;and in my view
column23: in spite of its insects and its diseases
column24: it ought inthe course of time to become the most prosperous of all our East andCentral African possessions
column25: and perhaps the financial driving wheelof all this part of the world. It is far from my desire to disparagethe East African Protectorate
column26: or to suggest diminution of activity orsupport. Both Protectorates are necessary to each other and shouldadvance together; but in view of their relative positions
column27: and lookingat the situation as it is to-day
column28: my counsel plainly is--'Concentrateupon Uganda!' Nowhere else in Africa will a little money go so far.Nowhere else will the results be more brilliant
column29: more substantial ormore rapidly realized.Cotton alone should make the fortune of Uganda. All the best qualitiesof cotton can be grown in the highest perfection
column30: a hundred thousandintelligent landowners occupying twenty thousand square miles ofsuitable soil are eager to engage in the cultivation. An industriousand organized population offers the necessary labour. Merely at therequest of the Government cotton has been planted experimentally on aconsiderable scale throughout Uganda. The figures of production--thoughof course they are only the first beginnings--show a surprisingexpansion. Great care is required
column31: and steps have already been takento secure that the quality of cotton exported from Uganda is notdeteriorated or its reputation prejudiced by hasty or untutoredaction
column32: that only the seeds which yield the best results should bedistributed
column33: and that no indiscriminate mixture should be permitted.The Government must control the culture. Experts must watch theginneries and educate the native cultivator. Roads must be made toenable the crop to be marketed. The scientific organization of thecotton-growing resources of Uganda has now been definitely undertaken.A special grant of 10

column1: ISFJ	 VIII.The Saint Ceases Not to Pray.  Prayer the Way to Recover WhatIs Lost.  All Exhorted to Pray.  The Great Advantage of Prayer
column2: Even to Those Who May Have Ceased from It.1. It is not without reason that I have dwelt so long on thisportion of my life.  I see clearly that it will give no onepleasure to see anything so base; and certainly I wish those whomay read this to have me in abhorrence

column1: ISFJ	 IX.The Means Whereby Our Lord Quickened Her Soul
column2: Gave Her Light inHer Darkness
column3: and Made Her Strong in Goodness.1. My soul was now grown weary; and the miserable habits it hadcontracted would not suffer it to rest
column4: though it was desirous ofdoing so.  It came to pass one day
column5: when I went into the oratory
column6: that I saw a picture which they had put by there
column7: and which hadbeen procured for a certain feast observed in the house.  It wasa representation of Christ most grievously wounded; and sodevotional
column8: that the very sight of it
column9: when I saw it
column10: movedme--so well did it show forth that which He suffered for us.So keenly did I feel the evil return I had made for those wounds
column11: that I thought my heart was breaking.  I threw myself on theground beside it
column12: my tears flowing plenteously
column13: and implored Himto strengthen me once for all
column14: so that I might never offend Himany more.2. I had a very great devotion to the glorious Magdalene
column15: andvery frequently used to think of her conversion--especially whenI went to Communion.  As I knew for certain that our Lord wasthen within me
column16: I used to place myself at His feet
column17: thinking thatmy tears would not be despised.  I did not know what I wassaying; only He did great things for me
column18: in that He was pleased Ishould shed those tears
column19: seeing that I so soon forgot thatimpression.  I used to recommend myself to that glorious Saint
column20: that she might obtain my pardon.3. But this last time
column21: before that picture of which I amspeaking
column22: I seem to have made greater progress; for I was nowvery distrustful of myself
column23: placing all my confidence in God.It seems to me that I said to Him then that I would not rise uptill He granted my petition.  I do certainly believe that thiswas of great service to me
column24: because I have grown betterever since. [1]4. This was my method of prayer: as I could not make reflectionswith my understanding
column25: I contrived to picture Christ as withinme; [2] and I used to find myself the better for thinking ofthose mysteries of His life during which He was most lonely.It seemed to me that the being alone and afflicted
column26: like a personin trouble
column27: must needs permit me to come near unto Him.5. I did many simple things of this kind; and in particular Iused to find myself most at home in the prayer in the Garden
column28: whither I went in His company.  I thought of the bloody sweat
column29: and of the affliction He endured there; I wished
column30: if it had beenpossible
column31: to wipe away that painful sweat from His face; but Iremember that I never dared to form such a resolution--my sinsstood before me so grievously.  I used to remain with Him thereas long as my thoughts allowed me
column32: and I had many thoughts totorment me.  For many years
column33: nearly every night before I fellasleep
column34: when I recommended myself to God
column35: that I might sleep inpeace
column36: I used always to think a little of this mystery of theprayer in the Garden--yea
column37: even before I was a nun
column38: because I hadbeen told that many indulgences were to be gained thereby.For my part
column39: I believe that my soul gained very much in this way
column40: because I began to practise prayer without knowing what it was;and now that it had become my constant habit
column41: I was saved fromomitting it
column42: as I was from omitting to bless myself with the signof the cross before I slept.6. And now to go back to what I was saying of the torture whichmy thoughts inflicted upon me.  This method of praying
column43: in whichthe understanding makes no reflections
column44: hath this property: thesoul must gain much
column45: or lose.  I mean
column46: that those who advancewithout meditation
column47: make great progress
column48: because it is done bylove.  But to attain to this involves great labour
column49: except tothose persons whom it is our Lord's good pleasure to lead quicklyto the prayer of quiet.  I know of some.  For those who walk inthis way
column50: a book is profitable
column51: that by the help thereof they maythe more quickly recollect themselves.  It was a help to me alsoto look on fields
column52: water
column53: and flowers. [3] In them I saw tracesof the Creator--I mean
column54: that the sight of these things was as abook unto me; it roused me
column55: made me recollected
column56: and reminded meof my ingratitude and of my sins.  My understanding was so dull
column57: that I could never represent in the imagination either heavenlyor high things in any form whatever until our Lord placed thembefore me in another way. [4]7. I was so little able to put things before me by the help of myunderstanding
column58: that
column59: unless I saw a thing with my eyes
column60: myimagination was of no use whatever.  I could not do as others do
column61: who can put matters before themselves so as to become therebyrecollected.  I was able to think of Christ only as man.  But soit was; and I never could form any image of Him to myself
column62: thoughI read much of His beauty
column63: and looked at pictures of Him.  I waslike one who is blind
column64: or in the dark
column65: who
column66: though speaking to aperson present
column67: and feeling his presence
column68: because he knows forcertain that he is present--I mean
column69: that he understands him to bepresent
column70: and believes it--yet does not see him.  It was thus withme when I used to think of our Lord.  This is why I was so fondof images.  Wretched are they who
column71: through their own fault
column72: havelost this blessing; it is clear enough that they do not love ourLord--for if they loved Him
column73: they would rejoice at the sight ofHis picture
column74: just as men find pleasure when they see the portraitof one they love.8. At this time
column75: the Confessions of St. Augustine were given me.Our Lord seems to have so ordained it
column76: for I did not seek themmyself
column77: neither had I ever seen them before.  I had a very greatdevotion to St. Augustine
column78: because the monastery in which I livedwhen I was yet in the world was of his Order; [5] and alsobecause he had been a sinner--for I used to find great comfort inthose Saints whom
column79: after they had sinned
column80: our Lord converted toHimself.  I thought they would help me
column81: and that
column82: as our Lord hadforgiven them
column83: so also He would forgive me.  One thing
column84: however
column85: there was that troubled me--I have spoken of it before [6]--ourLord had called them but once
column86: and they never relapsed; while myrelapses were now so many.  This it was that vexed me.But calling to mind the love that He bore me
column87: I took courageagain. Of His mercy I never doubted once
column88: but I did very oftenof myself.9. O my God
column89: I amazed at the hardness of my heart amidst so manysuccours from Thee.  I am filled with dread when I see how littleI could do with myself
column90: and how I was clogged
column91: so that I couldnot resolve to give myself entirely to God.  When I began to readthe Confessions
column92: I thought I saw myself there described
column93: andbegan to recommend myself greatly to this glorious Saint. When Icame to his conversion
column94: and read how he heard that voice in thegarden
column95: it seemed to me nothing less than that our Lord haduttered it for me: I felt so in my heart.  I remained for sometime lost in tears
column96: in great inward affliction and distress. O myGod
column97: what a soul has to suffer because it has lost the liberty ithad of being mistress over itself! and what torments it has toendure!  I wonder now how I could live in torments so great: Godbe praised Who gave me life
column98: so that I might escape from so fatala death!  I believe that my soul obtained great strength from HisDivine Majesty
column99: and that He must have heard my cry
column100: and hadcompassion upon so many tears.10. A desire to spend more time with Him began to grow within me
column101: and also to withdraw from the occasions of sin: for as soon as Ihad done so
column102: I turned lovingly to His Majesty at once.I understood clearly
column103: as I thought
column104: that I loved Him; but I didnot understand
column105: as I ought to have understood it
column106: wherein thetrue love of God consists.  I do not think I had yet perfectlydisposed myself to seek His service when His Majesty turnedtowards me with His consolations.  What others strive after withgreat labour
column107: our Lord seems to have looked out for a way to makeme willing to accept--that is
column108: in these later years to give mejoy and comfort.  But as for asking our Lord to give me eitherthese things or sweetness in devotion
column109: I never dared to do it;the only thing I prayed Him to give me was the grace never tooffend Him
column110: together with the forgiveness of my great sins.When I saw that my sins were so great
column111: I never ventureddeliberately to ask for consolation or for sweetness.  He hadcompassion enough upon me
column112: I think--and
column113: in truth
column114: He dealt withme according to His great mercy--when He allowed me to standbefore Him
column115: and when He drew me into His presence; for I sawthat
column116: if He had not drawn me
column117: I should not have come at all.11. Once only in my life do I remember asking for consolation
column118: being at the time in great aridities.  When I considered what Ihad done
column119: I was so confounded
column120: that the very distress I sufferedfrom seeing how little humility I had
column121: brought me that which Ihad been so bold as to ask for.  I knew well that it was lawfulto pray for it; but it seemed to me that it is lawful only forthose who are in good dispositions
column122: who have sought with alltheir might to attain to true devotion--that is
column123: not to offendGod
column124: and to be disposed and resolved for all goodness.  I lookedupon those tears of mine as womanish and weak
column125: seeing that I didnot obtain my desires by them; nevertheless
column126: I believe that theydid me some service; for
column127: specially after those two occasions ofgreat compunction and sorrow of heart
column128: [7] accompanied by tears
column129: of which I am speaking
column130: I began in an especial way to give myselfmore to prayer
column131: and to occupy myself less with those things whichdid me harm--though I did not give them up altogether.  But GodHimself
column132: as I have just said
column133: came to my aid
column134: and helped me toturn away from them.  As His Majesty was only waiting for somepreparation on my part
column135: the spiritual graces grew in me as Ishall now explain.  It is not the custom of our Lord to givethese graces to any but to those who keep their consciences ingreater pureness. [8]1. In the year 1555 (Bouix).2. See ch. iv.  10; ch. x.  1.3. See Relation

column1: ISFJ	 X.The Graces She Received in Prayer.  What We Can Do Ourselves.The Great Importance of Understanding What Our Lord Is Doingfor Us.  She Desires Her Confessors to Keep Her Writings Secret
column2: Because of the Special Graces of Our Lord to Her
column3: Which They HadCommanded Her to Describe.1. I used to have at times
column4: as I have said
column5: [1] though it used topass quickly away--certain commencements of that which I am goingnow to describe.  When I formed those pictures within myself ofthrowing myself at the feet of Christ
column6: as I said before
column7: [2] andsometimes even when I was reading
column8: a feeling of the presence ofGod would come over me unexpectedly
column9: so that I could in no wisedoubt either that He was within me
